{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Posters Evian-les-Bains 210417.jpg|thumb|French campaign posters before the May 2017 election.]] The '''2017 Macron e-mail leaks''' were [[news leak|leaks]] of more than 20,000 [[e-mails]] related to the campaign of [[Emmanuel Macron]] during the [[French presidential election, 2017|2017 French presidential elections]], two days before the final vote. The leaks garnered an abundance of media attention due to how quickly news of the leak spread throughout the [[Internet]], aided in large part by [[Internet bots|bots]] and [[spamming|spammers]]<ref name="CNBC 2017">{{cite web | author=CNBC | title=US far-right activists, WikiLeaks and Twitter bots help amplify Macron email leaks, researchers say | website=CNBC | date=7 May 2017 | url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/07/macron-email-leaks-far-right-wikileaks-twitter-bots.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> and drew accusations that the government of [[Russia]] under [[Vladimir Putin]] was responsible. The e-mails were shared by [[WikiLeaks]] and several American [[alt-right]] activists<ref name="Scottz 2017">{{cite web | last=Scott | first=Mark | title=U.S. Far-Right Activists Promote Hacking Attack Against Macron | website=The New York Times | date=6 May 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/06/world/europe/emmanuel-macron-hack-french-election-marine-le-pen.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> through social media sites like [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], and [[4chan]].<ref name="Brandom 2017">{{cite web | last=Brandom | first=Russell | title=Emails leaked in 'massive hacking attack' on French presidential campaign | website=The Verge | date=5 May 2017 | url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/5/15564532/macron-email-leak-russia-hacking-campaign-4chan | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
Originally posted on a filesharing site called [[Pastebin.com|PasteBin]], the e-mails had little to no effect on the final vote as they were dumped just hours before a 44-hour [[media blackout]] that is legally required by French electoral law.<ref name="Almasy 2017">{{cite web | last=Almasy | first=Steve | title=France: Emmanuel Macron's presidential campaign hacked | website=CNN | date=6 May 2017 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/05/europe/france-election-macron-hack-allegation/index.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Pastebin 2017">{{cite web | title=Emmanuel Macron Leaks | website=Pastebin | date=4 May 2017 | url=https://pastebin.com/gLpwpU2U | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
The campaign said the e-mails had been "fraudulently obtained" and that false documents were mingled with genuine ones in order "to create confusion and misinformation."<ref name="Press 2017">{{cite web | last=Press | first=Associated | title=French watchdog: Macron data mixed in with fake news in leak | website=Fox News | date=6 May 2017 | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/05/06/french-watchdog-macron-data-mixed-in-with-fake-news-in-leak.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Library 2017">{{cite web | last=Library | first=CNN | title=Emmanuel Macron Fast Facts | website=CNN | date=21 May 2017 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/21/europe/emmanuel-macron-fast-facts/index.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> Numerama, an online publication focusing on digital life, described the leaked material as "utterly mundane", consisting of "the contents of a [[hard drive]] and several emails of co-workers and [[La République En Marche!|En Marche]] political officials."<ref name="D dies in D 2017">{{cite web | title=Macron's emails got hacked. Here's why French voters won't hear much about them before Sunday's election. | website=Washington Post | date=6 May 2017 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/05/06/macrons-emails-got-hacked-heres-why-french-voters-wont-hear-much-about-them-before-sundays-election/ | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> [[United States Senator]] from [[Virginia]], [[Mark Warner]] cited the e-mail leak as a reinforcement of the cause behind the [[U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee]]'s investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]. Nonetheless, the Russian government denied all allegations of [[foreign electoral intervention]].<ref name="BBC News 2017">{{cite web | title=Macron blasts 'massive' hacking attack | website=BBC News | date=6 May 2017 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39827244 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Marine Le Pen and Vladimir Putin (2017-03-24) 01.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Marine Le Pen with [[Vladimir Putin]] in 2017.]] After the first round of the [[French presidential election, 2017|2017 French presidential election]] produced no majority winner, the top two candidates proceeded to a [[Two-round system|runoff election]] to be held on 7 May of that year. [[Emmanuel Macron]] of the [[La République En Marche!|En Marche!]] party and [[Marine Le Pen]] of the [[National Front (France)|National Front]] both began campaigning across [[France]] on their competing points of view.<ref name="Clarke Holder 2015">{{cite web | last=Clarke | first=Seán | last2=Holder | first2=Josh | title=French presidential election: first round results in charts and maps | website=the Guardian | date=24 June 2015 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/ng-interactive/2017/apr/23/french-presidential-election-results-2017-latest | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> The election was characterized by widespread dissatisfaction with the administration of [[François Hollande|President François Hollande]] and the French governmental establishment as a whole.<ref name="Beauchamp 2017">{{cite web | last=Beauchamp | first=Zack | title=The French election, explained in 9 maps and charts | website=Vox | date=25 April 2017 | url=https://www.vox.com/world/2017/4/25/15409924/french-election-charts | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
The election was widely regarded as a [[referendum]] between the [[Internationalism (politics)|internationalist]] [[centrism]] of Macron and the [[populism|populist]] [[Far-right politics|far-right]] ideology of Le Pen. After a slew of events considered to be detrimental to [[globalization]] and a triumph of [[nationalism]] and [[isolationism]], such as the [[Brexit referendum]], and the [[United States presidential election, 2016|election of Donald Trump]], many international observers viewed the French election as another possible trendsetting event for [[Western world|Western]] politics.<ref name="Horobin Kostov 2017">{{cite web | last=Horobin | first=William | last2=Kostov | first2=Nick | title=Macron and Le Pen Face Off in French Election Pitting Vision of Globalization Against Nationalism | website=WSJ | date=7 May 2017 | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/macron-and-le-pen-face-off-in-french-election-pitting-vision-of-globalization-against-nationalism-1494136806 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> Le Pen's [[Opposition to immigration|anti-immigration]], anti-[[NATO]], and [[Euroscepticism|anti-European Union]] stances attracted her the widespread support of far-right politicians and activists as far as the [[United States]], like [[Donald Trump]], and raised questions about possible [[appeasement]] of [[Russia]].<ref name="DW.COM 2017">{{cite web | title=Le Pen blasts EU, NATO, praises Trump - News - 24.02.2017 | website=DW.COM | date=24 February 2017 | url=http://www.dw.com/en/le-pen-blasts-eu-nato-praises-trump/a-37696454 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> Russian arms of state propaganda such as [[Russia Today]] and [[Sputnik News]] consistently portrayed Le Pen in a positive light, and her campaign had even secured millions of [[Euro]]s from a Russian lender in 2014.<ref name="Ferris-Rotman 2017">{{cite web | last=Ferris-Rotman | first=Amie | title=Russia ♥ Marine Le Pen | website=POLITICO | date=17 February 2017 | url=https://www.politico.eu/article/russia-%e2%99%a5-marine-le-pen-national-front-vladimir-putin-kremlin-france-elections/ | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
In the [[United States]], Le Pen was praised by [[Donald J. Trump|President Donald Trump]] on several occasions,<ref name="Quigley 2017">{{cite web | last=Quigley | first=Aidan | title=Trump expresses support for French candidate Le Pen | website=POLITICO | date=21 April 2017 | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/21/trump-supports-marine-le-pen-237464 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Obeidallah 2017">{{cite web | last=Obeidallah | first=Dean | title=Why Putin and Trump both like Le Pen | website=CNN | date=23 April 2017 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/23/opinions/trump-support-le-pen-opinion-obeidallah/index.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> and she saw widespread support and praise by large numbers of online conservative [[Internet trolls|trolls]] and [[Internet]] [[alt-right]] activists on [[social media]] platforms like [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], [[Reddit]], and [[4chan]], who simultaneously attacked Macron.<ref name="Scott 2017">{{cite web | last=Scott | first=Mark | title=In French Elections, Alt-Right Messages and Memes Don't Translate | website=The New York Times | date=1 May 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/technology/french-elections-alt-right-fake-news-le-pen-macron.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> These trolls used spamming of [[Internet meme]]s and [[misinformation]] as tactics to assail Macron; accusing him of being a "[[Globalism|globalist]] puppet" and a supporter of [[Islam]]ic immigration.<ref>Inside Marine Le Pen's "Foreign Legion" of American Alt-Right Trolls https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/05/marine-le-pen-alt-right-american-trolls/</ref> This was not a new strategy, it had been executed to much success during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 United States presidential election]]. Legions of pro-Trump Internet users and bots had spammed social media and rapidly spread anti-Clinton news releases and leaks across the web as was the case with the [[2016 Democratic National Committee email leak|Democratic National Committee leaks]] and the [[Podesta emails|John Podesta e-mail leaks]], allegedly with aid from the [[Moscow Kremlin|Kremlin]].<ref name="Washington Post 2017">{{cite web | title=Kremlin trolls burned across the Internet as Washington debated options | website=Washington Post | date=23 December 2017 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/kremlin-trolls-burned-across-the-internet-as-washington-debated-options/2017/12/23/e7b9dc92-e403-11e7-ab50-621fe0588340_story.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="The Daily Beast 2017">{{cite web | title=Russia Turns WikiLeaks CIA Dump Into Disinformation | website=The Daily Beast | date=8 March 2017 | url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/03/08/who-s-behind-the-massive-cia-leak | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Shane 2017">{{cite web | last=Shane | first=Scott | title=The Fake Americans Russia Created to Influence the Election | website=The New York Times | date=7 September 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/07/us/politics/russia-facebook-twitter-election.html | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/russian-bots-still-interfering-in-u-s-politics-after-election-expert|title=Russian bots still interfering in U.S. politics after election, says expert witness|last=Watson|first=Kathryn|date=30 March 2017|publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=20 September 2017}}</ref> Prior to the election, American national security officials warned the French government of the high probability of Russian digital meddling in the election, according to the [[Director of the National Security Agency]], [[Michael S. Rogers|Mike Rogers]].<ref name="Matishak 2017">{{cite web | last=Matishak | first=Martin | title=NSA chief: U.S. warned France about Russian hacks before Macron leak | website=POLITICO | date=9 May 2017 | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/09/us-warned-france-russia-hacking-238152 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
==E-mail leaks==
On Friday 5 May 2017, two days before the scheduled vote in the presidential election, the campaign of [[Emmanuel Macron]] claimed that it had been the target of a "massive hack". At the same time at least 9 [[gigabytes]] of data were dumped on an anonymous file sharing site called [[Pastebin]] using a profile called 'EMLEAKS'.<ref name="EMLEAKS 2017">{{cite web | last=Editorial | first=Reuters | title=French candidate Macron claims massive hack as emails leaked | website=U.S. | date=6 May 2017 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-election-macron-leaks/macron-campaign-emails-appear-to-be-leaked-online-idUSKBN1812AZ | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> The drop was made just hours before an [[election silence|election media blackout]] was due to take place in advance of Sunday's elections, as legally mandated under French electoral law which prevented Macron from issuing an effective response but also limited media coverage of the hack and subsequent leak.<ref name="EMLEAKS 2017" /><ref name="France 24 2017">{{cite web | title=French media rules prohibit election coverage over weekend | website=France 24 | date=6 May 2017 | url=http://www.france24.com/en/20170506-france-media-rules-prohibit-election-coverage-over-weekend-presidential-poll | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> The e-mails, totaling 21,075, along with other data was quickly posted to the anonymous message board, [[4chan]], where it was shared by [[alt-right]] activists, notably [[Jack Posobiec]], on Twitter.<ref name="The New Yorker 2017">{{cite web | title=The Far-Right American Nationalist Who Tweeted #MacronLeaks | website=The New Yorker | date=7 May 2017 | url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-far-right-american-nationalist-who-tweeted-macronleaks | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
The e-mail leak spread swiftly under the [[hashtag]] [[hashtag|#]]MacronLeaks on Twitter and Facebook. Within three and a half hours of first being used, #MacronLeaks had reached 47,000 tweets. On Jack Posobiec's [[Twitter]], the hashtag was retweeted 87 times within five minutes, likely pointing to the use of bots. [[WikiLeaks]] mentioned the leaks in subsequent tweets 15 times, contributing the most to the news' spread. Within a short period of time, #MacronLeaks was trending in France and was on a banner on the [[Drudge Report]] homepage. In another sign of bot use the ten most active accounts using the #MacronLeaks hashtag posted over 1,300 tweets in just over three hours. One particular account, posted 294 tweets in a span of two hours. Analysis shows that the hashtag was mentioned more times by American accounts than French ones, but posts concerning them were, by a slim margin, written more often in [[French language|French]] than [[English language|English]].<ref name="@DFRLab 2017">{{cite web | author=@DFRLab | title=Hashtag Campaign: #MacronLeaks – DFRLab – Medium | website=Medium | date=5 May 2017 | url=https://medium.com/dfrlab/hashtag-campaign-macronleaks-4a3fb870c4e8 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="The New Yorker 2017" />
The leaked e-mails were claimed to show evidence of criminal wrongdoing by Macron and his campaign including the committing of [[tax evasion]] and [[election fraud]], though these claims have not been substantiated and are likely false.<ref name="WIRED 2017">{{cite web | title=Hacked Macron Emails Leak Online Ahead of French Presidential Runoff Election | website=WIRED | date=5 May 2017 | url=https://www.wired.com/2017/05/macron-email-hack-french-election/ | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> A less suggestive examination of the e-mails by [[Numerama]], a French online publication focusing on technological news, described the leaked emails as "utterly mundane", consisting of "the contents of a hard drive and several emails of co-workers and En Marche political officials." Leaked documents included "memos, bills, loans for amounts that are hardly over-the-top, recommendations and other reservations, amidst, of course, exchanges that are strictly personal and private — personal notes on the rain and sunshine, a confirmation email for the publishing of a book, reservation of a table for friends, etc."<ref>{{cite news|author=Julien Cadot|title=#MacronLeaks : à 24h du vote, des opposants au candidat En Marche jouent leurs dernières cartes|url=http://www.numerama.com/politique/255850-macronleaks-a-24h-du-vote-des-opposants-au-candidat-en-marche-jouent-leurs-dernieres-cartes.html|publisher=Numerama|date=5 May 2017|accessdate=7 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170506180719/http://www.numerama.com/politique/255850-macronleaks-a-24h-du-vote-des-opposants-au-candidat-en-marche-jouent-leurs-dernieres-cartes.html|archivedate= 6 May 2017}}</ref>
===Reaction===
In response to the attack, [[Emmanuel Macron]] said it was "democratic [[destabilisation]], like that seen during the last presidential campaign in the United States" and said the hackers had mixed falsified documents with genuine ones, "in order to sow doubt and [[disinformation]]."<ref name="AFP 2018">{{cite web | author=AFP | title=Macron says hacked documents have been mixed with false ones to 'sow doubt and disinformation' | website=TheJournal.ie | date=12 January 2018 | url=http://www.thejournal.ie/macron-emmanuel-hacking-documents-french-election-3376197-May2017/ | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> Vice President of the National Front [[Florian Philippot]] and Le Pen adviser said in a tweet, "Will [[hashtag|#]]MacronLeaks teach us something that [[investigative journalism]] has deliberately killed?"<ref name="Trending 2017">{{cite web | last=Trending | first=BBC | title=Macron Leaks: the anatomy of a hack | website=BBC News | date=9 May 2017 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-39845105 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> The French election commission warned media in the country that publishing the e-mails or discussing them so close to the election would be a violation of the law and issued a statement that in part read, "On the eve of the most important election for our institutions, the commission calls on everyone present on internet sites and [[social media|social networks]], primarily the media, but also all citizens, to show responsibility and not to pass on this content, so as not to distort the sincerity of the [[ballot]]." <ref name="Savransky 2017">{{cite web | last=Savransky | first=Rebecca | title=France warns publishing candidate's hacked emails may 'distort' election | website=TheHill | date=6 May 2017 | url=http://thehill.com/homenews/news/332204-france-warns-against-publishing-candidates-hacked-emails | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> The leak did not appear to have any impact on the French presidential election which continued as scheduled and ended with a Macron victory by a margin of 32%.<ref name="Chrisafis 2017">{{cite web | last=Chrisafis | first=Angelique | title=Emmanuel Macron vows unity after winning French presidential election | website=the Guardian | date=8 May 2017 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/07/emmanuel-macron-wins-french-presidency-marine-le-pen | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> Despite this, French security officials commenced an investigation into the hacking shortly after the election.<ref name="CYBERDETECTIVE">{{cite web | last=Editorial | first=Reuters | title=French prosecutors investigate hacking of Macron campaign | website=U.S. | date=9 May 2017 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-election-cyber/french-prosecutors-investigate-hacking-of-macron-campaign-idUSKBN18525X | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
In the [[United States]], U.S. Senator from [[Virginia]] and ranking member of the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]], [[Mark Warner]] said the hacking and subsequent leak only emboldened his committee's investigation, and former [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] and Democratic presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] said in a tweet, "Victory for Macron, for France, the EU, & the world. Defeat to those interfering w/democracy. (But the media says I can't talk about that)."<ref name="Twitter 2018">{{cite web | title=Hillary Clinton on Twitter | website=Twitter | date=2 January 2018 | url=https://twitter.com/HillaryClinton/status/861317789537193988 | language=la | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>
==Perpetrators== [[File:APT28 APT29 Techniques - Malware.png|225px|thumb|right|Diagram illustrating how [[Fancy Bear]] illicitly obtains access to private servers.]] An assessment by Flashpoint, an American [[Computer security|cybersecurity]] firm, stated that they determined with "moderate confidence" that the group behind the hacking and leak was [[APT28]], better known as 'Fancy Bear', a hacking group with ties to [[Main Intelligence Directorate|Russian military intelligence]]. Metadata pulled from the dump revealed the name 'Georgy Petrovich Roshka', likely an alias, which has ties to a Moscow-based intelligence contractor. Many similarities, including the use of social media bots in an attempt to scrub metadata, also pointed to Fancy Bear.<ref name="Cyberscoop 2017">{{cite web | title=Researchers link Macron hack to APT28 with 'moderate confidence' | website=Cyberscoop | date=11 May 2017 | url=https://www.cyberscoop.com/researchers-link-macron-hack-to-apt28-with-moderate-confidence/ | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> However, on 1 June 2017, Guillaume Poupard, the head of France's premier cybersecurity agency said in an interview with the [[Associated Press]] the hack, "was so generic and simple that it could have been practically anyone".<ref name="AP News">{{cite web | title=The Latest: France says no trace of Russian hacking Macron | website=AP News | url=https://www.apnews.com/fc570e4b400f4c7db3b0d739e9dc5d4d | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref> On 9 May, two days after the election, [[Michael S. Rogers|Mike Rogers]], head of the [[National Security Agency|NSA]], said in sworn testimony with the [[United States Senate]] he had been made aware of Russian attempts to hack French election infrastructure,<ref>Testimony of Admiral Michael S. Rodgers, Commander of the U.S. Cyber Command, United States Cyber Command, Hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee, 9 May 2017</ref> though he did not mention anything related to the identities of those behind the Macron email hacking. This followed a French announcement that electronic voting for France's overseas citizens would be discontinued in light of cybersecurity threats.<ref name="Editorial 2017">{{cite web | last=Editorial | first=Reuters | title=France drops electronic voting for citizens abroad over cybersecurity | website=U.S. | date=6 March 2017 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-election-cyber/france-drops-electronic-voting-for-citizens-abroad-over-cybersecurity-fears-idUSKBN16D233 | access-date=12 January 2018}}</ref>

[[File:Nonie Darwish 1.jpg|250px|thumb|[[Nonie Darwish]], founder of Arabs For Israel]] '''Arabs for Israel''' ({{lang-ar|عرب من أجل إسرائيل}}) is an organization composed of ethnic Arabs who support [[Israel]] and [[Middle East]] peace.<ref name="Acorn">{{cite news|last=Fischer|first=Sophia|title=All about Arabs for Israel|newspaper=The Acorn|date=January 18, 2007}}</ref><ref name="JP0808">{{cite news|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1208246577144&pagename=JPArticle%2FShowFull|title=It's lonely being pro-Israel on campus|last=Diamond|first=Ilana|date=2008-08-15|publisher=Jerusalem Post|accessdate=2009-10-06}}</ref> The group was founded in February 2004 by [[Nonie Darwish]], an Egyptian-American [[Muslim]]-born [[Christian]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Chemla|first=Véronique|title=Nonie Darwish: 'An Arab for Israel'|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/2009/06/nonie_darwish_an_arab_for_isra.html|accessdate=27 June 2010|newspaper=American Thinker|date=June 27, 2009}}</ref> The group believes that “We can support the State of Israel and the Jewish religion and still treasure our Arab and Islamic culture”.<ref>Robert R Friedmann. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UBavSQq-2tEC&pg=PA549&dq=%22Arabs+For+Israel%22&hl=en&ei=YSkrTJHXAsH_lgei1ImqBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Arabs%20For%20Israel%22&f=false A Diary of Four Years of Terrorism and Anti-Semitism], 2005. pg. 549. {{ISBN|0-595-79301-0}}</ref>
Darwish maintains there are Muslims in America who speak out against terrorism and are pro-Israel, who are shunned by the organized Muslim community and cannot speak in mosques.<ref name="Acorn"/>
When asked why she started ''Arabs for Israel'', she said "to support Israel doesn't mean being anti-Arab. I love my people, but for peace to happen, we need a big leap, a new attitude; forgiveness and compassion." Darwish further said that she is afraid Israel will give away too much territory, making the country too small to defend. She concluded that "My Arab people are beautiful people, and I pray to God that they will find forgiveness in their hearts."<ref>{{cite news|last=GILBERT |first=LELA|title=An 'infidel' in Israel|url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=79372|accessdate=27 June 2010|newspaper=[[Jerusalem Post]]|date=2010-02-25 <!--16:54-->}}</ref>
The positions of ''Arabs For Israel'' include the acceptance for the existence of the State of Israel, a legitimate state that is not a threat but an asset in the [[Middle East]]. The group further states that "Every major World religion has a center of gravity. Islam has [[Mecca]], and [[Judaism]] has [[Jerusalem]]." The group says it is not "Anti-Islam, Anti-Arab, confrontational or hateful."

{{Infobox magazine | title = As Farpas | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = File:AsFarpas cover.png
| image_size = 230px | image_alt = | image_caption = One of the original covers of the magazine | editor = [[Ramalho Ortigão]] and [[Eça de Queirós]] | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = Social commentary | frequency = Monthly | circulation = | publisher = | founder = | founded = 1871-1882 | firstdate = | company = | country = | based = | language = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | website = | issn = | oclc = }} '''''As Farpas''''' (''The Barbs'') was a monthly publication started by the authors and journalists [[Ramalho Ortigão]] and [[Eça de Queirós]]. It first appeared in 1871, when the authors were, respectively, 35 and 26, and was published in [[Portugal]] until the end of 1882. Subtitled "The Country and Portuguese Society", the monthly issues presented a caricature of the society of the time and are considered an important contribution to Portuguese literature and the launching of critical journalism in the country.<ref name="Luso">{{cite web|title=As Farpas|url=https://www.luso-livros.net/Livro/farpas/|website=Luso Livros|accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref>
== History == ''As Farpas'' was initiated in the same year in which the so-called [[:pt: Conferências do Casino|Casino Conferences]] were held in Lisbon. At these conferences a group of young writers and intellectuals presented their suggestions to revolutionize Portuguese literature and cultural society of the time, based on the [[Realism (arts)| realist]] and [[Naturalism (literature)|naturalist]] philosophies of the French writer, [[Gustave Flaubert]] and others. It was the censorship imposed by the authorities on the conferences that is considered to have motivated, in large part, the authors to publish ''As Farpas''.<ref name="Luso"/><ref name="Passei">{{cite web|title=As farpas, de Eça de Queirós e Ramalho Ortigão|url=https://www.passeiweb.com/estudos/livros/as_farpas|website=Passei Web|accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref>
The magazine was published monthly, beginning in May 1871. At an early stage Eça left the publication to pursue a diplomatic career in [[Havana]], leaving responsibility with Ramalho, who continued with it until 1882. Articles in ''As Farpas'' were initially highly critical and ironic. They satirized the partisan journalism of the press; the economic, cultural, social and moral aspects of the so-called [[Regeneration (Portugal)| Regeneration period]] in the country; religion and the Catholic faith; the segregation of the social role of women; and [[Romanticism|romantic literature]]. For Portugal, ''As Farpas'' represented a new and innovative concept of journalism, one of ideas and social and cultural criticism. They provided an excellent sociological observation of day-to-day life in Portugal. For example, observations were made of markets and prisons and in administration offices. The authors observed fishermen at work and at home, families in church, people at the theatre and journalists in the newsrooms. Articles considered adultery, clerical life, economic decay, and political and cultural degradation, themes that would later be developed in the novels of Eça de Queirós.<ref name="Luso"/><ref name="Passei"/>
However, Eça's opinion about this work was not very positive. He said that they were “a collection of aged pimps that are not worth the paper on which they are printed” and described them as just a “huge laugh”. After his departure, the magazine under Ramalho Ortigão took on more of a pedagogical and moralizing tone, lacking the biting caricature provided by Eça de Queirós.<ref name="Luso"/><ref name="Passei"/>
From 1887 to 1890 the articles by Ramalho were reprinted in eleven volumes. The texts written by Eça were assembled in two volumes in 1890 with the title ''Uma Campanha Alegre'' (''A Cheerful Campaign'').
== External Links == Original copies of ''As Farpas'' can be downloaded from: *[http://purl.pt/256/4/ Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal] *[http://www2.senado.leg.br/bdsf/item/id/518751 Senada Federal Biblioteca Digital] ==References==

{{Infobox political party |name = Black Native Party |native_name = Partido Autóctono Negro |lang1 = |name_lang1 = |lang2 = |name_lang2 = |lang3 = |name_lang3 = |lang4 = |name_lang4 = |logo = |colorcode = #000000 |leader = |chairman = |chairperson = <!-- or chairman, but not both --> |president = |secretary_general = |spokesperson = |founder = |leader1_title = |leader1_name = |leader2_title = |leader2_name = |leader3_title = |leader3_name = |leader4_title = |leader4_name = |leader5_title = |leader5_name = |slogan = |founded = {{Start date|1936|05|23}} |dissolved = {{End date|1944|06|11}} |merger = |split = |predecessor = |merged = |successor = |headquarters = C/ Tristán Narvaja 1300, Montevideo<ref name="u50"/> |newspaper = ''Pan'' |ideology = Civil rights for Afro-Uruguayans |country = Uruguay }} The '''Black Native Party''' ({{lang-es|Partido Autóctono Negro}}, abbreviated '''PAN''') was a [[political party]] in [[Uruguay]] seeking to defend the rights of the [[Afro-Uruguayan]] community. The founders of the party were Afro-Uruguayan intellectuals whom sought to develop the party as a platform to elect Afro-Uruguayans to Congress.<ref name="u">UNHCR. ''[https://archive.is/20130416005302/http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,MRGI,,URY,,49749c853c,0.html World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples - Uruguay : Afro-Uruguayans]''</ref> The party was founded in 1936 and was close to the ''Nuestra Raza'' group.<ref name="p"/> The foundation of PAN followed the establishment of two other Black political parties in Latin America, in Cuba (1908) and Brazil (1931).<ref name="p"/>
==Founding== A first reference of the project to launch a Black political party can be found in the October 24, 1935, issue of ''Nuestra Raza''. The following issues of the journal carried more editorials and articles arguing for the foundation of the party. On May 9, 1936, a preliminary assembly of the party was held. Some 30 people participated in the event. Two preparatory bodies were named, a Reporting Committee and a Provisional Board. On May 23, 1936, the manifesto of the party (drafted by the Reporting Committee) was adopted at a party meeting.<ref name="u50">Gascue, Alvaro. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=fiDSEbKGSPMC&pg=PA50 Un intento de organización política de la raza negra en Uruguay - Partido Autóctono Negro]'', pp. 50–53.</ref> The manifesto of the party was formulated along [[Popular Front]] lines, calling for struggle against [[fascism]] and [[imperialism]].<ref name="p">Andrews, George Reid. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=EgyrwvOaXMgC&pg=PA201&lpg=PA103 Blackness in the white nation: a history of Afro-Uruguay]''. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2010, pp. 103–105.</ref>
Salvador Betervide was the founding chairman of the party.<ref name="p2"/> Other founders included Ventura Barrios and Elemo Cabral.<ref>[[Carole Boyce Davies|Boyce Davies, Carole]]. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mb6SDKfWftYC&pg=PA935 Encyclopedia of the African Diaspora: Origins, Experiences, and Culture]''. Santa Barbara, Calif: ABC-CLIO, 2008, p. 935.</ref> After Betervide's death from [[tuberculosis]] in 1936 the chairmanship of the party was taken over by Mario Méndez.<ref name="p2">Andrews, George Reid. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=EgyrwvOaXMgC&pg=PA201&lpg=PA96 Blackness in the white nation: a history of Afro-Uruguay]''. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2010. pp. 96–97, 201</ref> On January 5, 1937, the party was recognized by the Electoral Court. In March 1937 a new manifesto was issued, following similar lines as the original party manifesto.<ref name="u50"/>
==Local committees== On July 5, 1937, a local committee of the party was established in [[Rivera]]. On December 4, 1937, a General Assembly of the party was organized. On December 18, 1937, a local committee was set up in the town of [[Melo, Uruguay|Melo]].<ref name="u50"/>
==''Pan''== The party published the journal ''Pan'' ('Bread') as its organ. The first issue was published on April 15, 1937. Nine issues were published until December 1937.<ref>Lewis, Marvin A. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PMVm-e6MyxEC&pg=PA159 Afro-Uruguayan Literature: Post-Colonial Perspectives]''. Lewisburg, [Pa.]: Bucknell University Press, 2003, pp. 28, 159.</ref> Sandalio del Puerto was the editor of ''Pan'', until being replaced by Carmelo Gentile in October 1937.<ref name="u50"/>
==Electoral debacle== On March 5, 1938, the party convention was opened. The convention was a public event. The majority of the 22 participants came from Montevideo. The convention was chaired by Victoriano Rivero, Isabelino José Gares and Félix Tejera. At the meeting a draft candidate list for the upcoming elections was presented. On the second day of the convention (March 7), 16 people participated. The candidate list was approved with Mario Méndez as the top candidate. Other candidates were Carmelo Gentile, Pilar Barrios, Rufino Silva Gonzalez, Juan Carlos Martinez, Rolando R. Olivera, Victoriano Rivero, Cándido Guimaraes, Sandalio del Puerto and Roberto Sosa.<ref name="u50"/>
The party failed to win major support as the majority of Afro-Uruguayans preferred to vote for either of the two main parties.<ref name="u"/> The party launched a list of ten candidates ahead of the [[Uruguayan general election, 1938|1938 general election]]. The election campaign, carried out in Montevideo, centered around racial discrimination in employment in the state administration. The campaign had meager results, though, receiving a mere 87 votes. Following this humiliating experience, the party never contested elections again.<ref name="p"/>
==Split== PAN suffered a split in 1941. A group of Executive Committee members met on August 13, 1941, and voted to demote Méndez from his post as party chairman. Effectively two groups emerged that claimed to be the legitimate PAN, the group led by Méndez and another led by Anibal Eduarte, Ignacio Suarez Peña (chairman) and Ismael Arribio. I. Bello served as general secretary of the Méndez faction. On August 15, 1941, Méndez reported to police that properties at the PAN office had been stolen by the Suarez Peña faction. The Suarez Peña group responded by appealing to the Electoral Court that they be recognized as the genuine PAN. The Suarez Peña faction held a party assembly on August 23, 1941. The declaration of the assembly was signed by 49 persons.<ref name="u50"/>
In January 1942 the Méndez faction adopted a party hymn, composed by Victor Irrazabal and Carlos Tarama.<ref name="u50"/>
On January 23, 1942, the Electoral Court declared that it would not take sides in the dispute in PAN, arguing that it was not possible to determine who was the legitimate claimant to the name PAN.<ref name="u50"/>
==Reunification and dissolution== Méndez died on June 5, 1942. Following his death the two factions were reunited in October 1942.<ref name="u50"/>
The party was dissolved on June 11, 1944. The few properties of the party were donated to ''Nuestra Raza''.<ref name="u50"/>

[[File:Crowthorne - Broadmoor Warning Siren (geograph 2076019).jpg|thumb|One of the Broadmoor Sirens]] The '''Broadmoor Sirens''' are a series of thirteen warning sirens based in towns and villages surrounding [[Broadmoor Hospital]] in [[Crowthorne]], [[Berkshire]], England. They were first installed in 1952 and are based on [[air raid sirens]] with the intention of warning residents living near the [[Psychiatric hospital#Secure units|high-security psychiatric hospital]] of an escaped patient.<ref name=mail>{{cite web|last=Hudson |first=Christopher |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1088801/Broadmoor-hospital-finally-gives-secrets.html |title=Broadmoor hospital finally gives up its secrets |work=Daily Mail |date=2008-12-10 |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref>
== History == The Broadmoor Sirens were installed in 1952 in response to [[John Straffen|a patient]] escaping from Broadmoor and murdering a child in [[Farley Hill, Berkshire]] before being recaptured. They are similar to air-raid sirens but employ shutters to produce an alternating "high - low" warning tone.<ref name=star>{{cite web|last=Lyons |first=Rick |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/305181/Fears-for-kids-as-prison-sirens-axed |title=Fears for kids as prison sirens axed |work=Daily Star |date=2013-03-24 |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref> More sirens were added in the 1960s<ref>{{cite web|last=Slevin |first=Jennie |url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/news/councillors-hear-plans-future-broadmoor-7237837 |title=Councillors hear plans for future of Broadmoor sirens |publisher=Get Reading |date=2014-06-09 |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref> after discussions in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] raised the issue that the sirens' {{convert|2|mi|adj=on|spell=in}} radius was insufficient for nearby towns such as [[Camberley]] and [[Wokingham]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1960/feb/22/broadmoor-institution#column_25 |title=Broadmoor Institution (Hansard, 22 February 1960) |work=Hansard |date= |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref> The thirteen sirens, labelled A–M to distinguish each unit, were created with the intention of warning residents in surrounding towns and villages to remain in their homes and keep their children supervised following the escape of a Broadmoor patient. The sirens are activated as a test at 10am every Monday to ensure they are working.<ref name=mail /> The sirens are susceptible to electrical interference. In 2014, the Bracknell siren was activated accidentally during an electrical storm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bracknellnews.co.uk/news/roundup/articles/2014/07/18/102073-update-trust-apologises-after-three-hour-fault-with-broadmoor-siren-in-the-early-hours-of-this-morning/ |title=UPDATE: Trust apologises after three hour fault with Broadmoor siren in the early hours of this morning |work=Bracknell News |date=2014-07-18 |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref> The thirteen satellite sirens are due to be decommissioned during 2018, with one siren remaining in the hospital grounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wlmht.nhs.uk/bm/broadmoor-hospital/the-broadmoor-siren/ |title=The Broadmoor Siren |work=West London Mental Health, 6 January 2016}}</ref>
== Future == The last time the Broadmoor Sirens were activated because of an escape was in 1991, although they were activated in 1993 because of an attack at the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/dna/place-lancashire/A7414292 |title=The Broadmoor Siren |publisher=BBC |date=2007-11-19 |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref> In 2014, there were plans to remove seven of the thirteen sirens. This was because Broadmoor had added a second security fence around the hospital and intended to upgrade the remainder of the sirens so they had a {{convert|5|mi|adj=on|spell=in}} radius to improve on the two-mile radius of the 1952 sirens.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-berkshire-28251712 |title=Plan to scrap Broadmoor Hospital satellite sirens |publisher=BBC News |date=2014-07-11 |accessdate=2015-02-05}}</ref> Local residents objected to this on safety grounds due to there being sixteen [[primary schools]] within the radius of the sirens.<ref name=star /> It was reported on June 2, 2016 that the hospital plans to have twelve (possibly all thirteen) sirens scrapped by 2018 in favor of escape alerts via the [[internet]] and [[Twitter]].<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/02/broadmoors-plans-to-replace-warning-sirens-with-twitter-alerts-n/</ref> However, it is possible that Siren G, the siren nearest to the hospital, will remain in operation, though it will most likely be scrapped as well and replaced by a newer siren.
== References == <references />

{{original research|date=April 2018}} The term '''business oligarch'''[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/09/oleg-deripaska-michael-cherney-high-court Gun battles and 'extortion' in latest Russian oligarch legal battle], The Guardian, July 9, 2012{{failed verification|reason=No mention of 'business oligarch'|date=April 2018}} is almost a synonym of the term [[business magnate]],{{cn|date=April 2018}} borrowed by the English-speaking and western media from [[Russian language|post-Soviet]] parlance to label those [[businessmen]] who quickly acquired huge wealth in [[post-Soviet states]] (mostly [[Russia]] and [[Ukraine]]) during the [[privatization in Russia]] and in other post-Soviet states in the 1990s. Post-Soviet oligarchs are magnates who controls sufficient resources to influence national politics {{cite journal|last1= Guriev |first1= Sergei |last2= Rachinsky |first2= Andrei |title= The role of oligarchs in Russian capitalism |journal= Journal of Economic Perspectives |date=2005|pages=131-150|doi= 10.1257/0895330053147994|url= https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/0895330053147994 |volume=19|issue=1}}{{cite journal|last1= Chernenko|first1= Demid |title= Capital structure and oligarch ownership |journal= Economic Change and Restructuring |date=2018|pages=1–29|doi= 10.1007/S10644-018-9226-9|url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10644-018-9226-9 |volume=|issue= }} Business group might be defined as an oligarch if it satisfies the following conditions:
(1) owners are the largest private owners in the country (2) it possesses sufficient political power to promote its own interests (3) owners control multiple businesses, which intensively coordinate their activities.
A typical example of a post-Soviet oligarch entity is the [[Privat Group]] - a large [[Ukraine]]-based transnational business conglomerate comprising dozens of industrial companies in several markets, controlled by only three stakeholders, and not through the [[stock exchange]]. For the history of business oligarchs in post-Soviet Union states see: * [[Russian oligarch]]s * [[Ukrainian oligarchs]] More generally, an '''oligarch''' is a "member of an [[oligarchy]]; a person who is part of a small group holding power in a state". {{cite OED | oligarch}} Aristotle gave the concept of oligarchy some negative connotations, but the term does not necessarily imply wealth. {{cite web | url= http://global.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/427558/oligarchy | title= Oligarchy | publisher= Encyclopædia Britannica| date= June 20, 2013 | quote= Oligarchy, government by the few, especially despotic power exercised by a small and privileged group for corrupt or selfish purposes. [...] Aristotle used the term oligarchia to designate the rule of the few when it was exercised not by the best but by bad men unjustly. In this sense, oligarchy is a debased form of aristocracy, which denotes government by the few in which power is vested in the best individuals. Most classic oligarchies have resulted when governing elites were recruited exclusively from a ruling caste [...]. }} Compare "[[plutocrat]]". == References == {{Extreme wealth}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Business Oligarch}} [[Category:Social groups]] [[Category:Wealth concentration]] [[Category:Oligarchy]] [[Category:Post-Soviet states]] {{Business-stub}}

{{Chembox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 476998612 | Name = Calcium peroxide | ImageFile = Crystal structure of CaO2.jpg | ImageName = Calcium peroxide |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 14096 | UNII_Ref = {{fdacite|correct|FDA}} | UNII = 7FRO2ENO91 | InChI = 1/Ca.O2/c;1-2/q+2;-2 | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 48233 | SMILES = [Ca+2].[O-][O-] | InChIKey = LHJQIRIGXXHNLA-UHFFFAOYAW | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/Ca.O2/c;1-2/q+2;-2 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = LHJQIRIGXXHNLA-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo = 1305-79-9 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | PubChem = 14779 | RTECS = EW3865000 }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = CaO2 | MolarMass = 72.0768 g/mol | Density = 2.91 g/cm3 | Appearance = white or yellowish powder | Odor = odorless | Solubility = decomposes | MeltingPt= ~ | MeltingPtC = 355 | MeltingPt_notes = (decomposes) | BoilingPt = | pKa = 12.5 | RefractIndex = 1.895 | MagSus = -23.8·10−6 cm3/mol }} |Section3={{Chembox Structure | CrystalStruct = Orthorhombic{{cite journal |journal=RSC Advances |year=2013 |title= Structures and stabilities of alkaline earth metal peroxides XO2 (X = Ca, Be, Mg) studied by a genetic algorithm |first1=X. |last1=Zhao |doi=10.1039/C3RA43617A |last2=Nguyen |first2=M.C. |last3=Wang |first3=C.Z. |last4=Ho |first4=K.M. |url=https://zenodo.org/record/1230026/files/article.pdf }} | SpaceGroup = Pna21 | Coordination = 8 }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | ExternalSDS = | EUClass = | RPhrases = | SPhrases = | LD50 = >5000 mg/kg (oral, rat)
>10000 mg/kg (dermal, rat) }} |Section8={{Chembox Related | OtherAnions = [[Calcium oxide]] | OtherCations = [[Strontium peroxide]]
[[Barium peroxide]]
[[Sodium peroxide]] }} }} '''Calcium peroxide''' or '''calcium dioxide''' is the [[inorganic compound]] with the formula CaO2. It is the [[peroxide]] (O22−) salt of Ca2+. Commercial samples can be yellowish, but the pure compound is white. It is almost insoluble in [[water]].{{Ullmann | title = Peroxo Compounds, Inorganic | author = Harald Jakob, Stefan Leininger, Thomas Lehmann, Sylvia Jacobi, Sven Gutewort | doi = 10.1002/14356007.a19_177.pub2}} ==Structure and stability== As a solid, it is relatively stable against decomposition. In contact with water however it hydrolyzes with release of oxygen. Upon treatment with [[acid]], it forms [[hydrogen peroxide]]. ==Preparation== Calcium peroxide is produced by combining [[calcium]] salts and [[hydrogen peroxide]]: :Ca(OH)2 + H2O2 → CaO2 + 2 H2O The octahydrate precipitates upon the reaction of [[calcium hydroxide]] with dilute [[hydrogen peroxide]]. Upon heating it dehydrates. ==Applications== It is mainly used as an oxidant to enhance the extraction of precious metals from their ores. In its second main application, it is used as a [[food additive]] under the [[E number]] E930 it is used as [[flour bleaching agent]] and [[improving agent]]. In agriculture it is used in the presowing treatments of [[rice seed]]. Also, calcium peroxide has found use in the [[aquaculture]] to oxygenate and disinfect water. In the ecological restoration industry it is used in the treatment of soils. Calcium peroxide is used in a similar manner to [[magnesium peroxide]] for environmental restoration programs. It is used to restore soil and groundwater contaminated with petroleum by the process of enhanced in-situ [[bioremediation]]. ==References== {{reflist|1}} {{E number infobox 920-929}} {{Calcium compounds}} {{oxygen compounds}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Calcium Peroxide}} [[Category:Peroxides]] [[Category:Calcium compounds]] [[Category:Food additives]] [[Category:Bleaches]] [[Category:Disinfectants]] [[Category:Oxidizing agents]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Castle Hill rebellion | partof = | image = Battle of VinegarHill.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = An 1804 watercolour depicting the rebellion and hangings | date = 4–5 March 1804 | place = [[Castle Hill, New South Wales|Castle Hill]], [[Colony of New South Wales]], [[Australia]] | coordinates = | result = Rebellion crushed | combatant1 = Convict insurgents | combatant2 = {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[British Army]] | commander1 = Phillip Cunningham
William Johnston | commander2 = [[George Johnston (New South Wales)|George Johnston]] | strength1 = 233Silver 1989, p. 103. | strength2 = Total: 97
* 67 armed civilians * 1 mounted trooper * 29 military personnel | casualties1 = 15 dead
9 executed
23 exiled | casualties2 = None | casualties3 = | notes = }} The '''Castle Hill rebellion''' of 1804 was a [[rebellion]] by [[Convictism in Australia|convicts]] against colonial authority of the [[British Empire|British colony]] of [[Colony of New South Wales|New South Wales]] in the [[Castle Hill, New South Wales|Castle Hill]] area, in [[Sydney]]. The rebellion culminated in a battle fought between convicts and the [[colonial forces of Australia]] on 5 March 1804 at [[Rouse Hill, New South Wales|Rouse Hill]], dubbed the '''Second Battle of Vinegar Hill''' after the first [[Battle of Vinegar Hill]] which had taken place in 1798 in [[Ireland]]. It was the first and only major convict uprising in [[History of Australia|Australian history]] suppressed under [[martial law]]. On 4 March 1804, according to the official accounts 233 convicts led by Philip Cunningham (a veteran of the [[Irish Rebellion of 1798]], as well as [[mutiny]] on the convict transport ship [[Anne (1799 ship)|''Anne'']]) escaped from a prison farm intent on "capturing ships to sail to Ireland". In response, martial law was quickly declared in the Colony of New South Wales. The mostly Irish rebels, having gathered reinforcements, were hunted by the colonial forces until they were sequestered on 5 March 1804 on a hillock nicknamed Vinegar Hill. Under a [[White flag|flag of truce]], Cunningham was arrested and troops charged and the rebellion was crushed by a [[Raid (military)|raid]]. Nine of the rebel leaders were executed and hundreds were punished before martial law was finally revoked a week after the battle.{{TOC limit|2}} ==Background== ===Rising=== Many convicts in the [[Castle Hill, New South Wales|Castle Hill]] area had been involved in the 1798 rebellions in Ireland and subsequently transported as exiles-without-trial to the Colony of New South Wales from late 1799. Phillip Cunningham, a veteran of the 1798 rebellion, and William Johnston, another Irish convict at Castle Hill, planned an uprising in which over 685 convicts at Castle Hill intended to meet with nearly 1,100 convicts from the [[Hawkesbury River]] area, rally at [[Constitution Hill, New South Wales|Constitution Hill]], and march on [[Parramatta, New South Wales|Parramatta]] and then [[Sydney]] (Port Jackson) itself. According to Helen Mackay, their goal was to establish Irish rule in the colony and obtain ships for those that wanted to return to Ireland to help revive the failed [[Irish Rebellion of 1803]].Mackay 2016, p. 125.{{cite web |url=http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/castle_hill_convict_rebellion_1804 |title=Castle Hill convict rebellion 1804 |author=Whitaker, Anne-Maree |work=[[Dictionary of Sydney]] |year=2009 |accessdate=3 January 2017}} On the evening of 4 March 1804, John Cavenah set fire to his hut at Castle Hill at 8:00 as the signal for the rebellion to begin. While this fire was not seen by the convicts at Green Hills, today's Windsor, on the Hawkesbury River, Cunningham activated the plan to gather weapons, ammunition, food and recruits from local supporters and the government farm at Castle Hill.Silver 1989, p. 81. With Cunningham leading, about 200 to 300 rebels broke into the Government Farm's buildings, taking firearms, ammunition, and other weapons. The constables and overseers were overpowered and the rebels then went from farm to farm on their way to Constitution Hill at Parramatta, seizing more weapons and supplies including rum and spirits, and recruiting others to join their cause.Silver 1989, pp. 82–86. Their move had been informed from the intelligence gathered a year previous when 12 convicts de-camped from Castle Hill scouring the surrounding districts seeking out friends and sympathisers. On capture each and every one had the same story – they were heading to China by crossing over the [[Blue Mountains (New South Wales)|Blue Mountains]].According to Silver (p. 62), due to limited geographical knowledge, at the time many Irish convicts believed that China lay just beyond the Blue Mountains and that they could escape their incarceration by making their way over the mountains. ===Initial government response=== [[File:Castle hill irish rebellion of 1804 australia.jpg|thumb|240px|[[Castle Hill, New South Wales|Castle Hill]] Irish rebellion.]] When news of the uprising spread there was great panic amongst the colony of around 5,000 inhabitants with officials such as [[Samuel Marsden]] fleeing the area by boat, escorting [[Elizabeth Macarthur]] and her children, as an informer had advised that an attack would be made on the farm to draw troops away from Parramatta.Silver 1989, pp. 87–88. In Sydney, following news from Parramatta, Governor [[Philip Gidley King|Philip King]] set off alone for Parramatta to assume command, while Lieutenant Colonel [[William Paterson (explorer)|William Paterson]], the lieutenant governor, called out the guard. One hundred and forty men from [[HMS Calcutta (1795)|HMS ''Calcutta'']], as well as the Sydney Loyal Association militia, took over guard duties, and a [[New South Wales Corps]] contingent of 56 personnel including Lieutenant William Davies{{cite web |url=http://www.historyaustralia.org.au/ifhaa/bios/davis.htm |title= William Davis |author=Brown, Scott |work=IFHAA Biographies Library |accessdate=5 January 2017}} and Quartermaster Sergeant Thomas Laycock were dispatched to march through the night to bolster the garrison at Parramatta. Meanwhile, the provost marshal, Thomas Smyth, was sent ahead to contact Major [[George Johnston (British Marines officer)|George Johnston]] at Annandale. The troops from Sydney arrived at 1:30 am, and after a quick inspection an advanced guard was sent to the west of the town.Silver 1989, pp. 90–91. Johnston arrived at Government House in Parramatta about four hours later not long after King had declared martial law under the Mansfield doctrine of [[posse comitatus]].In 1780, a series of riots in London were eventually suppressed by the use of soldiers. In discussing the legal ramifications of this action Parliament agreed with Lord Chief Justice Mansfield who declared that all civil riots should be put down by civil authorities and the posse comitatus, never by military authorities. Further that even if soldiers comprise the posse comitatus they are deemed to be acting in a civil capacity and are thus subject to civilian laws. This policy of soldier as civilian came to be known as the Mansfield Doctrine and was to be the controlling policy on the role of the posse comitatus in England.Silver 1989, pp. 94 & 106. King's proclamation of martial law applied to a wide area extending from Castle Hill to the Hawkesbury and Nepean areas, and empowered citizens in the area to detain those who lacked the appropriate passes. A curfew had also been enacted and an amnesty declared, which gave those who were involved 24 hours to surrender. On Johnston's arrival at Parramatta, King delivered his orders, in writing, to Johnston and then verbally to his small detachment. Johnston was to proceed to the western gate of the park around Government House, where the rebels had been seen a few hours earlier. If they were not there, he was ordered to exploit towards [[Toongabbie]] and Castle Hill to locate them and then await further orders. He was also empowered to fire upon anyone who did not obey his directions.Silver 1989, pp. 94–95. Shortly after 5:00 am, Johnston set out to locate the main rebel force. In addition to the troops he had brought with him, a number of civilians volunteered along with the 36 armed members of the Parramatta [[Loyal Association]]{{cite web |url=http://www.lancers.org.au/site/The_Military_at_Parramatta.asp |title=The Military at Parramatta: A Talk Given to the Parramatta and District Historical Society on 19 September 1962 |author=Vernon, P |publisher= Royal New South Wales Lancers Lancer Barracks and Museum |accessdate=2 January 2017}} militia were also called out and took over defence of the town. Over 50 enrolled in a reserve militia combined with the NSW Corps to march out and confront the rebels.Silver 1989, pp. 97 & 103. Johnston decided to advance in two columns, one which he led himself towards Toongabbie, and another under a subaltern, Davies, which was sent along the Castle Hill Road.Silver 1989, p. 96. === Rebels prepare === Meanwhile, the rebels at Constitution Hill ([[Toongabbie]]) were having difficulties co-ordinating their force as several parties, including one of around 70 men under Samuel Humes, had lost their way in the night. Nevertheless, Cunningham and William Johnston commenced drilling their men,Silver 1989, p. 94. while a party unsuccessfully tried to enter Parramatta,Some accounts state that about 30 rebels were killed or wounded in fighting with government forces around the western gate. See Mackay 2016. where they were to set fire to a building to signal other conspirators to begin converging on Constitution Hill.Silver 1989, pp. 88–90. Cunningham, being involved in two previous rebellions and the [[Ann (ship)|mutiny on the ''Anne'']], knew from experience that the most important element of a rebellion or uprising would be secrecy. However, there were two defections: an Irish convict overseer named Sloane, and Lewis Bulger.Silver 1989, pp. 77–79. The commandant at Parramatta, Captain Edward Abbott, who had warning of the rebellion as it was happening, commenced defensive measures and sent a message to the governor in Sydney.Silver 1989, p. 80. [[File:George Johnston.jpg |thumb|right|George Johnston, who led the military response to the rebellion, as a lieutenant colonel in 1810.]] With their courier, John Griffen, having had second thoughts about passing on the instructions Cunningham had given him to pass on to Brian Furey and subsequently being arrested,Silver 1989, pp. 77–80. the call out messages to [[Windsor, New South Wales|Windsor]], Parramatta and Sydney failed, and the uprising was confined to west of the Parramatta area. After fruitlessly waiting for a signal of a successful internal takeover of Parramatta, and the non-appearance of reinforcements, Cunningham was forced to withdraw from Parramatta to Toongabbie to re-assess his strategy. Having already declared his hand, and deprived of both surprise and facing a superior and well disciplined force of [[Red coat (British army)|Red Coats]] and enthusiastic militia, the uprising under Cunningham had no recourse but to withdraw west towards the Hawkesbury hoping to pick up more recruits and meeting his missing forces on the way to add to his forces.Coulthard-Clark 1998, p. 2. Knowing that going forward would only see more death and possible routing, they quickly moved westward hoping to join up with those now heading east from Green Hills (Windsor) to meet in the area of today's [[Rouse Hill, New South Wales|Rouse Hill]] and [[Kellyville, New South Wales|Kellyville]], recruiting or impressing against their will a number of convicts along the way. (Those later giving evidence stated they were press-ganged into serviceSilver 1989, p. 111. in hope of lessening their punishment.) During this phase they obtained around a third of the entire colony's armaments.Silver 1989, p. 86. Their numbers had dwindled to several hundred, eventually reaching a total of 233. During the short period of the rebellion, Cunningham was elected "King of the Australian Empire", and his followers declared the area "New Ireland".{{cite web|url=http://www.myplace.edu.au/decades_timeline/1800/decade_landing_20.html?tabRank=2&subTabRank=4|title=Australia in the 1800s: Castle Hill Rebellion|work=My Place: For Teachers|publisher=Australian Children's Television Foundation and Education Services Australia|accessdate=3 January 2015}} == Battle == Major Johnston's contingent, wearied by their night march, needed time to close with the retreating rebels, who were reported to number around 400, so he rode after them with a small mounted party to implement delaying tactics, while the rest of his party completed the {{convert|4|mi|km}} march to Toongabbie. Initially, it was believed that the rebels were at Toongabbie, but on arrival Johnston was informed that they had moved on to Constitution Hill. A small party under a corporal was sent to outflank this position, while an assault force of around a dozen men advanced on the summit, only to find it abandoned, with the rebels having moved off towards the Hawkesbury, about {{convert|17|mi|km}} away. As the morning progressed, the heat of the day threatened to stymie the efforts of the marching troops who were poorly equipped for the pursuit.Silver 1989, p. 97. Nevertheless, about {{convert|6|mi|km}} from Toongabbie,Silver 1989, p. 100. Johnston located the main rebel party of around 230 to 260 men near Rouse Hill,Coulthard-Clark 1998, p. 3. Johnston first sent his mounted trooper on to call the rebels to surrender and take the benefit of the Governor's amnesty for early surrender. This failing, he dispatched Roman Catholic priest Father James Dixon to appeal to them. Next he rode up himself, appealing to them, then got their agreement to hear Father Dixon again.Silver 1989, pp. 100–101. Meanwhile, the pursuing forces had closed up and Major Johnston with Trooper Analzark came again to parley, calling down the leaders Cunningham and Johnston from the hill. Demanding their surrender, he received the response "Death or Liberty" from Cunningham,Silver 1989, p. 102. to which some were reported to have added "and a ship to take us home".{{cite web |url=http://www.nma.gov.au/online_features/defining_moments/featured/castle_hill_rebellion |title=Castle Hill Rebellion |work=Defining Moments in Australian History |publisher=National Museum Australia |accessdate=2 January 2017}} With the [[NSW Corps]] and militia now formed up in firing lines behind him Major Johnston and Analzark produced pistols duping, while under truce, the two leaders of the uprising, and escorting them back to the Red Coat's lines. Quartermaster Sergeant Thomas Laycock, on being given the order to engage, directed over fifteen minutes of musket fire, then charged cutting Cunningham down with his cutlass. The now leaderless rebels first tried to fire back, but then broke and dispersed.Silver 1989, pp. 102–104. During the battle (at least) fifteen rebels had fallen, according to the official reports, Major Johnston prevented further bloodshed and killings by threatening his troops with his pistol tempering their enthusiasm.Silver 1989, pp. 103–105. Several convicts were captured and others killed in the pursuit which went up to Windsor all day until late in the night, with new arrivals of soldiers from Sydney joining in the search for rebels. On Wednesday, 7 March Governor King announced that those that surrendered before 10 March would receive leniency and following this large parties who lost their way in the night turned themselves in under the amnesty or made their way back to Castle Hill where a large party of about 70 under Samuel Humes were captured by a detachment of the Loyal Parramatta Association.Silver 1989, pp. 106–108. == Aftermath == According to the official records of the day, around 230 were eventually brought in over next few days and of the convicts directly engaged in the battle, 15 were killed, and 9 including the ringleaders Cunningham and Johnston were executed,{{cite web|year=2004 |url=http://www.battleofvinegarhill.com.au/whofought.htm |title=Who fought at the Battle of Vinegar Hill |work=The Battle of Vinegar Hill |publisher=www.battleofvinegarhill.com.au |accessdate=19 July 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060813184804/http://www.battleofvinegarhill.com.au/whofought.htm |archivedate=13 August 2006 |df=dmy }} Derived from the book ''The Battle of Vinegar Hill'' by Lynette Ramsey Silver, published by Watermark Press, updated and expanded 2002.According to Silver (p. 132): Phillip Cunningham (executed at Windsor), William Johnston (executed at Castle Hill), John Neale (executed at Castle Hill), George Harrington (executed at Castle Hill), Samuel Humes (executed at Parramatta), Charles Hill (executed at Parramatta), Jonothan Place (executed at Parramatta), John Brannan (executed at Sydney), Timothy Hogan (executed at Sydney) with two, Johnson and Humes, subjected to [[gibbeting]]. Two men, John Burke and Bryan McCormack, were reprieved and detained at the Governor's pleasure, seven were whipped with 200 or 500 lashes then allotted to the [[Coal River Precinct|Coal River]] chain gang,According to Silver (pp. 132–133): John Griffin, Neil Smith, Bryan Burne, Connor Dwyer, David Morrison, Cornelius Lyons and Owen McDermot. while 23 others, including Cavenah were sent to the [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] coal mines.Silver 1989, pp. 132–133. Another 34 prisoners were placed in irons until they could be "disposed of". It is not known whether some, or all of them, were sent to the Coal River. Of the remaining rebels, some were put on good behaviour orders against a trip to [[Norfolk Island]], while the majority were pardoned and allowed to return to their places of employment as having been coerced into the uprising.Mackay 2016, pp. 128.Silver 1989, p. 133. Cunningham, badly wounded but still alive, was court martialled under the martial law and hanged at the Commissariat Store at Windsor, which he had bragged he would burn down.Silver 1989, p. 106. Initially, military officers were intent on hanging a token number of those captured having convened a military court at the Whipping GreenPresent day Prince Alfred Square, Parramatta. but this was quickly stopped by Governor Gidley King fearful of the repercussions.Silver 1989, pp. 108–110. Martial law was eventually lifted on 10 March 1804, but this did not end the insurgency. Irish plots continued to develop, keeping the Government and its informers vigilant, with military call out rehearsals continuing over the next three years. Governor King remained convinced that the real inspirers of revolt had kept out of sight, and had some suspects sent to Norfolk Island as a preventive measure.Silver 1989, pp. 114–118. ===Location === {{Location map | Australia Sydney | width = 350 | float = right | border = black | caption = Location of the battlefield within the modern Sydney area | alt = | relief = | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label = Battlefield | label_size = 50 | position = | background = | mark = Red pog.svg | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = 33.7293 | lat_dir=S | lon_deg = 151.0040 | lon_dir=E }} The battle site is believed to be to the east of the site of the [[Rouse Hill House|Rouse Hill Estate]], and it is likely that [[Richard Rouse (Australian colonial settler)|Richard Rouse]], a staunch establishment figure, was subsequently given his grant at this site specifically to prevent it becoming a significant site for Irish convicts. "The Government Farm at Castle Hill", a plot of land around {{convert|60|ha|acre}}, was added in March 1986 to the (now defunct) [[Register of the National Estate]], as a special place of international and Australian significance.{{cite web |url=http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/ahdb/search.pl?mode=place_detail;search=list_code%3DRNE%3Bplace_id%3D2964%3Bkeyword_PD%3Don%3Bkeyword_SS%3Don%3Bkeyword_PH%3Don%3Blatitude_1dir%3DS%3Blongitude_1dir%3DE%3Blongitude_2dir%3DE%3Blatitude_2dir%3DS%3Bin_region%3Dpart;place_id=2964 |title=Castle Hill Settlement Site, Old Castle Hill Rd, Castle Hill, NSW, Australia |work=Australian Heritage Database |accessdate=3 January 2017}} Residential development has significantly diminished the area of the prison town. Less than {{convert|20|ha|acre}} has remained undeveloped and conserved, as Castle Hill Heritage Park, established in 2004. There is a sculpture near the battle site at Castlebrook Cemetery commemorating the sacrifice. However, there is some debate as to where the battle actually occurred.{{cite web|last=Riley |first=Cameron |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2003 |url=http://www.hawkesburyhistory.org.au/articles/Battle_of_Vinegar.html |title=The 1804 Australian Rebellion and Battle of Vinegar Hill |work=Historical Influences on the Hawkesbury |publisher=The Hawkesbury Historical Society |accessdate=19 July 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819034722/http://hawkesburyhistory.org.au/articles/Battle_of_Vinegar.html |archivedate=19 August 2006 |df= }} === Commemoration === The [[Anniversary|bicentenary]] of the rebellion was commemorated in 2004, with a variety of events.{{cite web | year = 2004 | url = http://www.battleofvinegarhill.com.au/program.htm | title = Program | work = The Battle of Vinegar Hill | publisher = www.battleofvinegarhill.com.au | accessdate = 19 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615184238/http://www.battleofvinegarhill.com.au/program.htm|archivedate=15 June 2006 }} The re-enactment in 2004 was significant in that exact numbers were recruited to form the rebels, the militia and the military. The event was held in close proximity to the original site on a similar landscape. The re-enactment was recorded by the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]].{{cite web |url=http://splash.abc.net.au/web/splash#!/media/2428320/the-second-battle-of-vinegar-hill |title=The Second Battle of Vinegar Hill |publisher=ABC Splash |accessdate=2 January 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://splash.abc.net.au/home#!/media/2428288/what-is-living-history- |title=What is 'living history'? |publisher=ABC Splash |accessdate=2 January 2017}} In addition, the battle has been depicted on screen. An Australian 1978 TV series, ''[[Against the Wind (TV series)|Against the Wind]]'', included a dramatization over two episodes of the build-up to and ultimate defeat of the rebellion.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076974/ |title=Against the Wind (TV mini-series) |work=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=2 January 2017}} A monument commemorating the battle was erected at Castlebrook Memorial Park, on Windsor Road, Rouse Hill. It was dedicated on 5 March 1988.{{cite web |url=http://monumentaustralia.org.au/australian_monument/display/22941 |title=Battle of Vinegar Hill Memorial |publisher=Monument Australia |accessdate=2 January 2017}} == See also == *[[Bathurst Rebellion]] *[[List of Irish rebellions]] == References == ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== *{{cite book|last=Coulthard-Clark|first=Chris|title=Where Australians Fought: The Encyclopaedia of Australia's Battles|year=1998|edition=1st|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=St Leonards, New South Wales|isbn=1-86448-611-2}} * {{cite book |last=Mackay |first=Helen |chapter=The 'Vinegar Hill' rebellion/ uprising of 1804 |url=http://www.cawb.com.au/uploads/1/0/4/5/10456711/the_battle_for_windsor_bridge_-_personal_stories_print_version.pdf |editors=Ballantyne, Cheryl; Campbell, Michael |title=The Battle of Windsor Bridge – Personal Stories |pages=125–129 |publisher=CAWB |accessdate=3 January 2016}} *{{cite book |last=Silver |first=Lynette Ramsay |title=The Battle of Vinegar Hill: Australia's Irish Rebellion, 1804 |year=1989 |publisher=Doubleday |location=Sydney, New South Wales |isbn=0-86824-326-4}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last=Whitaker |first=Anne-Maree |year=2004 |title=Mrs Paterson's Keepsakes: The Provenance of Some Significant Colonial Documents and Paintings |journal=Journal of the Royal Australian Historical Society |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb4817/is_2_90/ai_n29138925/ }} {{Prison riots and uprisings}} {{Convicts in Australia}} {{coord|33.7293|S|151.0040|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Castle Hill Convict Rebellion}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1804]] [[Category:1804 in Australia]] [[Category:Convictism in New South Wales]] [[Category:Rebellions in Australia]] [[Category:Prison uprisings]] [[Category:1804 riots]] [[Category:Violent non-state actor incidents]] [[Category:19th century in New South Wales]] [[Category:March 1804 events]] [[Category:Civil wars involving the states and peoples of Oceania]] [[Category:The Hills Shire]]
