[[Xan Carballo]], second general secretary. |website= |footnotes= }} The '''National Inter-Union of the Galician Workers''' ({{lang-gl|Intersindical Nacional dos Traballadores Galegos}}, INTG) was a Galician union with an [[Anticapitalism|anticapiltalist]], [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] and [[Galician nationalism|Galician nationalist]] ideology, direct heir of the Intersindical Nacional GalegaGalician National Inter-Union (ING), and precursor of [[Confederación Intersindical Galega]] (CIG). ==Foundation== The INTG was founded after the 1980 union elections, in which the two [[Galician nationalism|galician nationalist]] unions ran together; the [[Intersindical Nacional Galega]] (ING) and the [[Central de Traballadores Galegos]]in [[English language]]: Galician Workers Central (CTG). Between both, they got 1679 delegates (17.5%), which was more than the 15% of the union representation required by the Spanish law to become a ''more representative union'' - which in practice, allows the presence of the union in the negotiations of the collective agreements. The strategic success represented by the unity of the ING and the CTG favored the consolidation of the unification of both unions into a single combative, [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] and [[Galician nationalism|Galician nationalist]] union, which occurred definitely in 1981 when both unions united and formed the INTG. ==Early years (1982-1984)== In January 1982, the INTG celebrated its First Congress, where [[Lois Ríos]] was elected as general secretary. That same year, the Confederación Sindical Galega,Galician Union Confederation a split of the Spanish [[Unión Sindical Obrera]] (USO) and linked with the [[Galician Socialist Party]]. In that year's election, the INTG got 1649 delegates (18.5%). In 1983, [[Xan Carballo]], one of the main figures of the [[Communist Party of National Liberation]] (PCLN), was elected as the new general secretary of the INTG. ===The three strikes against naval conversion=== After the so-called [[Pactos de la Castellana]], the central government wanted to reconvert the public shipbuilding companies, the INTG, jointly with the Spanish trade unions [[CCOO]] and [[Unión General de Trabajadores|UGT]] called a strike in the [[comarca]] of [[Vigo]], one of the most affected cities by the new state policy., on April 15, 1983. The tension continued to grow in the following months, and the INTG, called for a [[general strike]] on February 14, 1984: the first [[general strike]] since the [[Spanish Civil War]],http://folgaxeral.info/ which was supported [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]] (BNG), [[Galiza Ceibe-OLN]], the [[PSG-EG]], the [[Communist Movement of Galicia|MCG]] and the [[Galician Revolutionary Students]]. CCOO and UGT also called to [[General strike|strike]], but only in the cities of [[Vigo]] and [[Ferrol, Spain|Ferrol]], where the main Galician [[shipyard]]s were located. The success of the strike of February 14 made [[CCOO]] join INTG in to the call for another [[general strike]], to be celebrated on July 12. The [[Unión General de Trabajadores|UGT]] did not called to strike, due to its closed relationship with the [[PSOE]], which at the time ruled on [[Spain]]. Further, the UGT accused CCOO and the INTG of trying to create a climate of violence and unrest in [[Galicia, Spain|Galicia]], and compared the situation in Galicia to that in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]]. The [[General strike|strike]] was considered a great success by the INTG and the rest of the [[Galician nationalism|galician nationalist]] organizations, which facilitated a third call to a general strike for November 29 of that same year (1984), then against the ''New social pact'' (AES) signed between UGT and the Spanish government, which advanced in line of the dismantling of the shipbuilding industry in the [[Ria de Vigo]] area. Again, CCOO joined the call of the INTG and the strike was a new success, mobilizing a large number of Galician [[comarcas]] and especially in [[Vigo]], where there were more than 100 000 protesters. The three general strikes generated a considerable increase in support for [[Galician nationalism|nationalist]] unionism through the figure of INTG. ==The split of the 1984 and the recovery of 1990== Despite the great success of the [[general strike]]s led by the INTG, that same year of 1984 a critical internal current with the union leadership and its general secretary, [[Xan Carballo]], emerged. This current, called Converxencia Sindical NacionalistaNationalist Union Convergence (CSN), was linked with the PSG-EG, founded that year and directed by [[Camilo Nogueira]]. The CSN decided to abandon the INTG in 1985, forming the [[Confederación Xeral de Traballadores Galegos-Intersindical Nacional]] (CXTG), which celebrated in October of that year its first Congress. In it, [[Fernando Acuña]] was elected secretary general of the new union. In the union elections of 1986, the [[Confederación Xeral de Traballadores Galegos-Intersindical Nacional|CXTG]] won 1087 delegates and the INTG 1067 delegates. On the other hand, the relationship with [[Confederación Xeral de Traballadores Galegos-Intersindical Nacional|CXTG]] also produced a fracture inside the INTG, that explained the four different candidates to the internal elections in the Third Congress, held in 1987. In it, the list close to the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc|BNG]] reached 6 representatives, the list close to the [[Galician People's Front|FPG]] reached 3 representatives and the candidacy close to the gained [[Assembleia do Povo Unido|APU]] 1 representative. [[Manuel Mera]] was elected secretary general. ==Recovering unity: creation of the CIG== On April 2, 1990, the INTG and [[Confederación Xeral de Traballadores Galegos-Intersindical Nacional|CXTG]] made an unified list to the union elections, known as the Converxencia Intersindical Galega.Galician Unions Convergence After the unified candidacy in 1990, there was an organic unification in 1993, giving birth to the [[Confederación Intersindical Galega]]. [[Fernando Acuña]], who came from the [[Confederación Xeral de Traballadores Galegos-Intersindical Nacional|CXTG]], and that was linked to the [[Galician Unity]] party, was appointed as the general secretary in the first two conferences of the [[Trade union|union]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} * Beramendi, X.G. and Núñez Seixas, X.M. (1996): ''O nacionalismo galego''. [[A Nosa Terra]], [[Vigo]] * Beramendi, X.G. (2007): ''De provincia a nación. Historia do galeguismo político''. Xerais, [[Vigo]] * Manuel Anxo Fernández Baz, ''A formación do nacionalismo galego contemporáneo (1963-1984)'', Laiovento, 2003. {{Portal|Organized labour}} {{Galician nationalism |state=collapsed}} [[Category:1980 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:National trade union centers of Spain]] [[Category:Trade unions in Spain]] [[Category:European Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1980]] [[Category:Trade unions disestablished in 1993]] [[Category:Socialism]] [[Category:Galician nationalism]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{multiple issues| {{More citations needed|date=July 2016}} {{undue weight|date=January 2014}} }} {{Infobox aircraft occurrence | occurrence_type = Accident | name = Aerolinee Itavia Flight 870 | image = Itavia DC-9 I-TIGI.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = I-TIGI, the aircraft involved in the accident, 1973. | date = 27 June 1980 | type = Disputed. Main theories: shot down (proposed by the [[Italian government]]); terrorist bomb (proposed by British [[Air Accidents Investigation Branch|AAIB]]) | site = [[Tyrrhenian Sea]]
near [[Ustica]], Italy | coordinates = | passengers = 77 | crew = 4 | fatalities = 81 | injuries = | missing = | survivors = 0 | aircraft_type = [[McDonnell Douglas DC-9|McDonnell Douglas DC-9-15]] | tail_number = [http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19800627-0 I-TIGI] | origin = [[Guglielmo Marconi Airport|Guglielmo Marconi Airport (BLQ)]] | stopover = | stopover0 = | last_stopover = | destination = [[Palermo International Airport|Palermo International Airport (PMO)]] | aircraft_name = | operator = [[Aerolinee Itavia]] }} {{coord|38.839494|N|13.425293|E|type:event_region:IT|display=title}} On 27 June 1980, '''Itavia Flight 870''' (IH 870, AJ 421), a [[McDonnell Douglas DC-9]] passenger jet en route from [[Bologna]] to [[Palermo]], Italy, crashed into the [[Tyrrhenian Sea]] between the islands of [[Ponza]] and [[Ustica]], killing all 81 people on board. Known in Italy as the '''Ustica massacre''' ("strage di Ustica"), the disaster led to numerous investigations, legal actions and accusations, and continues to be a source of controversy, including claims of conspiracy by the Italian government and others. Former Italian President [[Francesco Cossiga]] attributed the crash to a missile fired from a [[French Navy]] aircraft, despite contrary evidence presented in a 1994 report. On 23 January 2013, Italy's top criminal court ruled that there was "abundantly" clear evidence that the flight was brought down by a missile.{{Cite news |title=Italian court: Missile caused 1980 Mediterranean plane crash; Italy must pay compensation |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=23 January 2013 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/italian-court-missile-caused-1980-mediterranean-plane-crash-italy-must-pay-compensation/2013/01/28/8337ede8-6976-11e2-9a0b-db931670f35d_story.html}} ==Aircraft== {{Location map many | Italy | relief = | width = | float = right | caption = The location of the crash site between the departure and destination airports | alt = | | label1 = Bologna Guglielmo Marconi | label1_size = | position1 = | background1 = | mark1 = Green pog.svg | mark1size = | link1 = | lat1_deg = 44 | lat1_min = 32 | lat1_sec = 07 | lat1_dir = N | lon1_deg = 11 | lon1_min = 17 | lon1_sec = 19 | lon1_dir = E | | label2 = Crash site | label2_size = | position2 = | background2 = | mark2 = Airplane silhouette.svg | mark2size = 10 | link2 = | lat2_deg = 38 | lat2_min = 50 | lat2_sec = 22 | lat2_dir = N | lon2_deg = 13 | lon2_min = 25 | lon2_sec = 31 | lon2_dir = E | | label3 = Palermo Punta Raisi | label3_size = | position3 = right | background3 = | mark3 = | mark3size = | link3 = | lat3_deg = 38 | lat3_min = 10 | lat3_sec = 55 | lat3_dir = N | lon3_deg = 13 | lon3_min = 5 | lon3_sec = 58 | lon3_dir = E }} The aircraft flown as Aerolinee Itavia Flight 870, a [[McDonnell Douglas DC-9|McDonnell Douglas DC-9-15]], was manufactured in 1966 and acquired by the airline on 27 February 1972 with the serial number CN45724/22 and registration I-TIGI (formerly N902H,{{cite web|url=http://www.planespotters.net/Production_List/McDonnell-Douglas/DC-9/45724,N902H-Hawaiian-Airlines.php |title=I-TIGI Itavia McDonnell Douglas DC-9-15 – cn 45724 / ln 22 |publisher=planespotters.net |accessdate=2 February 2013}} operated by [[Hawaiian Airlines]]). ==Flight history== On 27 June 1980 at 20:08 [[Central European Time|CET]], the plane departed with a delay of one hour and 53 minutes from [[Bologna Guglielmo Marconi Airport]] for a scheduled service to [[Palermo Punta Raisi Airport]], Sicily. With 77 passengers aboard, captain Domenico Gatti and first officer Enzo Fontana were at the controls, with two flight attendants.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_zLUiLCx3vY The flight was designated IH 870 by air traffic control, while the military radar system used AJ 421. Contact was lost shortly after the last message from the aircraft was received at 20:37, giving its position over the [[Tyrrhenian Sea]] near the island of Ustica, about {{convert|120|km|-1}} southwest of [[Naples]]."Italian DC-9 lost off Sicily." ''[[Flight International]]''. 5 July 1990. p. [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1980/1980%20-%201610.html?search=Itavia 2]. ([http://www.flightglobal.com/FlightPDFArchive/1980/1980%20-%201610.PDF Direct PDF link], [https://www.webcitation.org/6S94UYSdp?url=http://www.flightglobal.com/FlightPDFArchive/1980/1980%20-%201610.PDF Archive]) Two [[Italian Air Force]] [[F-104]]s were scrambled at 21:00 from [[Grosseto Airport|Grosseto Air Force Base]] to locate the accident area and search for any survivors, but failed to do so because of poor visibility.{{Citation needed|reason=two f-104 were in flight before the crash, landing at Grosseto air base. no information about F-104 crash-related take off from Grosseto, but hh3f helicopters from Ciampino.|date=June 2009}} Floating wreckage and bodies were later found in the area. There were no survivors among the 81 people on board. ==Official investigation== After years of investigations, no official explanation or final report has been provided by the [[Politics of Italy|Italian government]]. In 1989, the Parliamentary Commission on Terrorism, headed by Senator [[Giovanni Pellegrino]], issued an official statement concerning the disappearance of Flight 870, which became known as the "Ustica Massacre" (''Strage di Ustica''). The definitive sentence asserted: :"The DC9 incident occurred following a military interception action, the DC9 was shot down, the lives of 81 innocent citizens were destroyed by an action properly described as an act of war, real war undeclared, a covert international police action against our country, which violated its borders and rights." :''"L'incidente al DC9 è occorso a seguito di azione militare di intercettamento, il DC9 è stato abbattuto, è stata spezzata la vita a 81 cittadini innocenti con un'azione, che è stata propriamente atto di guerra, guerra di fatto e non dichiarata, operazione di polizia internazionale coperta contro il nostro Paese, di cui sono stati violati i confini e i diritti."'' The perpetrators of the crime remain unidentified. The court, unable to proceed further, declared the case archived. In July 2006, the re-assembled fragments of the DC-9 were returned to Bologna from [[Pratica di Mare Air Force Base]] near Rome. In June 2008, Rome prosecutors reopened the investigation into the crash after former [[List of Presidents of the Italian Republic|Italian President]] [[Francesco Cossiga]] (who was prime minister when the incident occurred) said that the aircraft had been shot down by French warplanes.[http://uk.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUKL2264892420080622 Italy Reopens Probe Into 1980 Plane Crash: Media], Reuters, 22 June 2008 On 7 July 2008, a claim for damages was served to the French President. ===High treason charges against Italian Air Force officials=== The role of [[Italian Air Force]] personnel in the tragedy is unclear. Several Air Force officials have been investigated and brought to court for a number of offenses, including falsification of documents, perjury, abuse of office and aiding and abetting. Four generals were charged with [[high treason]], on the allegations that they obstructed government investigation of the accident by withholding information about air traffic at the time of Ustica disaster. The first ruling, on 30 April 2004, pronounced two of the generals, Corrado Melillo and Zeno Tascio, not guilty of high treason. Lesser charges against a number of other military personnel were also dropped. The abuse-of-office charge was no longer valid (because of legislative changes), and the other allegations could not be pursued further after the expiration of the [[statute of limitations]], as the disaster had occurred more than 15 years prior. For this same reason, action could not be taken against the other two generals, Lamberto Bartolucci and Franco Ferri. However, the ruling did not acquit them, and they were still alleged to be guilty of treason. In 2005, an appeals court ruled that the accusations were made on insufficient grounds. On 10 January 2007, the [[Court of Cassation (Italy)|Italian Court of Cassation]] upheld this ruling and conclusively closed the case, fully acquitting Bartolucci and Ferri of any wrongdoing. In June 2010, Italian President [[Giorgio Napolitano]] urged all Italian authorities to cooperate in the investigation of the incident.{{cite news|last=Troendle|first=Stefan|publisher=Tagesschau|title=Napolitano fordert Aufklärung des Absturzes von Ustica|date=27 June 2010|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/ustica108.html|accessdate=27 June 2010|quote=Zum Jahrestag der Flugzeugkatastrophe von Ustica hat Italiens Staatspräsident Giorgio Napolitano alle staatlichen Stellen aufgefordert, daran mitzuarbeiten, das Unglück endlich aufzuklären. Es müsse eine befriedigende und ehrliche Rekonstruktion der Ereignisse stattfinden, damit alle Unklarheiten beseitigt würden.}} In September 2011, a Palermo civil tribunal ordered the Italian government to pay 100 million euros ($137 million) in civil damages to the relatives of the victims for failing to protect the flight, concealing the truth and destroying evidence.{{Cite news |title=Italy court fines government $137 million over mysterious crash of plane over Ustica |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=13 September 2011 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/italy-court-fines-government-137-million-over-mysterious-crash-of-plane-over-ustica/2011/09/13/gIQArlRxPK_story.html }} On 23 January 2013, the Civil Cassation Court ruled that there was "abundantly" clear evidence that the flight was brought down by a stray [[missile]], confirming the lower court's order that the Italian government must pay compensation. In April 2015, an appeals court in Palermo confirmed the rulings of the 2011 Palermo civil tribunal and rejected an appeal by the state attorney.{{Cite news |title=Ustica, Corte d’Appello conferma: "Il Dc-9 venne abbattuto da un missile" |date=8 April 2015 |newspaper=[[Il Fatto Quotidiano]] |url=http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2015/04/08/ustica-corte-dappello-conferma-dc-9-venne-abbattuto-missile/1573006 }} ==Hypotheses on the causes== {{refimprove section|date=June 2013}} Speculation at the time and in the years since has been fueled in part by media reports, military officials' statements and [[Air traffic control|ATC]]/[[Flight recorder|CVR]] recordings. Adding to the widespread conjecture was the observation of radar images showing trails of objects moving at high speeds. ===Terrorist bomb=== After the [[Years of Lead (Italy)|series of bombings that hit Italy in the 1970s]], a terrorist act was the first explanation to be proposed. As the flight was delayed in Bologna by almost three hours, a bomb's timer may have been set to actually cause an explosion at the Palermo airport, or on a further flight of the same plane. The technical commission supporting a 1990 judicial enquiry reported that an explosion in the rear toilet, and not a missile strike, was the only conclusion supported by the wreckage analysis.[http://aviation-safety.net/pubs/other/Taylor_paper_Ustica_illustrated.pdf A. Frank Taylor, "A Case History Involving Wreckage Analysis: Lessons from the Ustica investigations"] ([https://www.webcitation.org/6SAEPRdmq?url=http://aviation-safety.net/pubs/other/Taylor_paper_Ustica_illustrated.pdf Archive]) Fourteen years after the accident, a 1994 joint investigation carried out by the British [[Air Accidents Investigation Branch]] (AAIB) and Italian investigators found conclusive physical evidence (as per the wreckage recovered) that a bomb had indeed exploded mid-flight in the rear lavatory. A large section of the aircraft's fuselage around the lavatory was never recovered (presumably having disintegrated in the explosion). A test explosion in a DC-9 lavatory showed the resulting deformation in the surrounding structure to be almost identical to that of the incident aircraft.See: * A. Frank Taylor (March 1995) "Accident to Itavia DC-9 near Ustica, 27 June 1980: wreckage and impact information & analysis," ''International Society of Air Safety Investigators Forum'' (Paris, October 1994), '''28''' (1) : 6 ff. Available on-line at: [http://www.stragi80.it/documenti/ricostruzioni/taylor2.PDF Strage di Ustica] * A. F. Taylor (1998) "The study of aircraft wreckage: the key to accident investigation," ''Technology, Law and Insurance'', '''3''' (2) : 129–147. * A. Frank Taylor, "A Case History Involving Wreckage Analysis: Lessons from the Ustica investigations" (Cranfield, Bedfordshire, England, UK: Cranfield University, 1998, revised: 2006). Available on-line at: [http://aviation-safety.net/pubs/other/Taylor_paper_Ustica_illustrated.pdf Aviation-Safety.net] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6SAEPRdmq?url=http://aviation-safety.net/pubs/other/Taylor_paper_Ustica_illustrated.pdf |date=28 August 2014 }} However, the Italian high courts dismissed this final report as insignificant to their own investigation, and the report was never considered. ===Missile strike during military operation=== Major sources in the Italian media have alleged that the aircraft was shot down during a [[dogfight]] involving Libyan, United States, French and Italian Air Force fighters in an assassination attempt by NATO members on an important Libyan politician, perhaps even Libyan leader [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]], who was flying in the same airspace that evening.{{Cite journal |title=Italy's Darkest Night |author=Thomas Van Hare |journal=Historic Wings |date=27 June 2012 |url=http://fly.historicwings.com/2012/06/italys-darkest-night/ }} This version was supported in 1999 by investigative magistrate Rosario Priore,[https://www.theguardian.com/elsewhere/journalist/story/0,,1825348,00.html The Mystery of Flight 870], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 July 2006 {{en icon}} who said in his concluding report that his investigation had been deliberately obstructed by the Italian military and members of the secret service, in compliance with NATO requests. According to the Italian media, documents from the archives of the Libyan secret service passed on to [[Human Rights Watch]] after the [[Battle of Tripoli (2011)|fall of Tripoli]] show that Flight 870 and the Libyan MiG were attacked by two French jets.{{Cite journal |title=Libyan secret documents said to uncover Ustica tragedy… and how Gaddafi escaped to Malta unscathed |author=Noel Grima |date=18 September 2011 |journal=[[The Malta Independent]] |url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2011-09-18/news/libyan-secret-documents-said-to-uncover-ustica-tragedy-and-how-gaddafi-escaped-to-malta-unscathed-298884/ }} On 18 July 1980, 21 days after the Aerolinee Itavia Flight 870 incident, the wreckage of a Libyan MiG-23, along with its deceased pilot, was found on the Sila Mountains in Castelsilano, Calabria, southern Italy, according to official reports.{{cite book | last=Cooper | first=T. | last2=Grandolini | first2=A. | title=Libyan Air Wars: Part 1: 1973-1985 | publisher=Helion, Limited | series=Africa@War | year=2015 | isbn=978-1-910777-51-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aVbdCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA41 | language=ms | access-date=2018-03-14 | page=41}} ==Conspiracy theories== Several [[conspiracy theories]] explaining the disaster persist.{{Cite journal |title=Conspiracy Buffs Gain in Court Ruling on Crash |author=Elisabetta Povoledo |date=10 February 2013 |journal=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/11/world/europe/itavia-flight-870-ruling-adds-support-to-a-theory.html }} For example, the vessel that carried out the search for debris on the ocean floor was French, but only US officials had access to the aircraft parts they found. Several radar reports were erased and several Italian generals were indicted 20 years later for obstruction of justice. The difficulty the investigators and the victims' relatives had in receiving complete, reliable information on the Ustica disaster has been popularly described as ''un muro di gomma'' (literally, a rubber wall),{{Cite journal |title=Italian Obsession: Was Airliner Shot Down? |author=ALAN COWELL |date=10 February 1992 |journal=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/10/world/italian-obsession-was-airliner-shot-down.html }} because investigations just seemed to "bounce back". ==Memorial== [[File:Museo ustica.JPG|thumb|right|Remains of the plane at the Museum for the Memory of Ustica, Bologna, Italy]] On 27 June 2007, the Museum for the Memory of Ustica was opened in Bologna. The museum is in possession of parts of the plane, which are assembled and on display, including almost all of the external fuselage. The museum also has objects belonging to those on board that were found in the sea near the plane. [[Christian Boltanski]] was commissioned to produce a site-specific installation. The installation consists of: * 81 pulsing lamps hanging over the plane * 81 black mirrors * 81 loudspeakers (behind the mirrors) Each loudspeaker describes a simple thought/worry (e.g. "when I arrive I will go to the sea") All the objects found are contained in a wooden box covered with a black plastic skin. A small book with the photos of all objects and various information is available to visitors upon request. ==Dramatization== {{refimprove section|date=January 2014}} {{undue weight|date=January 2014}} The accident was featured in the 13th season of the Canadian documentary series ''[[Mayday (Canadian TV series)|Mayday]]'' in an episode entitled "[[List of Mayday episodes#Season 13 .282013.29|Massacre Over The Mediterranean]]". The film examined the heavy public pressure placed upon investigators to uncover the cause of the accident, and also considered the three separate technical investigations that occurred. It ultimately advanced the conclusions of the third and final technical investigation, which concluded that the wreckage ruled out a missile and pointed to an explosion in or near the rear lavatory. The documentary was highly critical of the Italian judiciary's failure to officially release the third technical investigation to the public, or to consider its conclusion that missiles were not responsible. Interviewee David Learmount of [[Flight International]] magazine made the following comments: * "The judiciary in Italy just found Frank Taylor's findings inconvenient. I don't think they ordered it not to be published, they just made a decision that they wouldn't publish it." * "I'm sorry, but Italy is a dreadful place to have an aviation accident. If you want the truth, you're less likely to find it there than just about anywhere else in the world." * "Frank Taylor's team didn't reach any conclusions except ones which were based on hard physical evidence. There was no theorizing going on." Frank Taylor, a British investigator involved in the third technical inquest, also commented: :"We discovered quite clearly that somebody had planted a bomb there, but nobody on the legal side, it would appear, believed us and therefore, so far as we are aware, there has been no proper search for who did it, why they did it, or anything else. As an engineer and an investigator I cannot see why anybody would want to consider anything other than the truth."2014-05-01. URL:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_zLUiLCx3vY. Accessed: 1 May 2014. (Archived by WebCite® at https://www.webcitation.org/6PFsar96P?url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_zLUiLCx3vY A 1991 Italian film by [[Marco Risi]], ''[[The Rubber Wall]]'', tells the story of a journalist in search of answers to the many questions left open by the accident. The film theorises on a few possible scenarios, including the possibility that the DC-9 was mistakenly shot down during an aerial engagement between NATO and Libyan jet fighters. ==See also== *[[Air France Flight 1611]] *[[Uncontrolled decompression#Notable decompression accidents and incidents|Notable decompression accidents and incidents]] *[[1956 B-47 disappearance]] *[[List of unsolved deaths]] *[[Cold War (1979–85)]] *[[Operation Gladio]] *[[Strategy of tension]] *[[Years of Lead (Italy)]] {{Portal bar|Aviation|Disasters|Italy|1980s|Death}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External link) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130502234741/http://www.airdisaster.com/cgi-bin/view_details.cgi?date=06271980®=I-TIGI&airline=Itavia AirDisaster.Com Accident Synopsis of Flight 870] *[http://www.planecrashinfo.com/1980/1980-32.htm Accident details] at [http://www.planecrashinfo.com/ planecrashinfo.com] *{{IMDb title|id=0102487|title=Il Muro di gomma}}, film about the accident *[https://www.theguardian.com/elsewhere/journalist/story/0,,1825348,00.html The mystery of flight 870] – Guardian Newspaper. *[http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=62e_1172060667 (Video) The truth about Ustica's disaster (6/27/1980)] *https://www.webcitation.org/6SAEPRdmq?url=http://aviation-safety.net/pubs/other/Taylor_paper_Ustica_illustrated.pdf {{Aviation accidents and incidents in 1980}} page.title: Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|date=August 2014}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{Third-party|date=August 2014}} }} The '''Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage''' is an international award established in 2010 by the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/home/ |title=Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage |last=[[G. P. "Bud" Peterson]] President Georgia Institute of Technology |publisher=Georgia Institute of Technology |accessdate=4 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120909052514/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/home/ |archivedate= 9 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> in recognition of the late [[Ivan Allen Jr.]] A Georgia Tech alumnus, Allen became a pivotal leader during America's struggle for racial integration during the 1960s. While mayor of [[Atlanta, Georgia]], USA (1962–1970), Allen risked his place in society, his political future, and his life when he testified before the U.S. Senate Commerce Committee in support of what became the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]].<ref>Mayor: Notes on the Sixties. Ivan Allen Jr., Paul Hemphill. Simon and Schuster, New York 1971.</ref>
The Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage recognizes individuals who, like Mayor Allen, stand up for moral principles and render service to humanity without regard for personal or professional peril. Recipients positively affect public discourse in spite of the risk to their careers, their livelihoods, and even their lives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu |title=President's Welcome | ivanallenprize2.gatech.edu | Georgia Institute of Technology | Atlanta, GA |publisher=Ivanallenprize.gatech.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}}</ref> The Prize is funded in perpetuity by a grant from the Wilbur and Hilda Glenn Family Foundation. It was awarded for the first time on March 15, 2011, replacing the [[Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Progress and Service]], which had been awarded from 2001–2010 to prominent Georgians.<ref name="gatech1">[http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=63120 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119201522/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=63120 |date=January 19, 2012 }}</ref>
==Prize recipients== ===Beatrice Mtetwa=== Prominent human rights attorney Beatrice Mtetwa has been named recipient of the Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage, an award given to individuals who, by asserting moral principle, have positively affected public discourse at the risk of their careers, livelihoods, and sometimes lives.
The Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage will be presented to Beatrice Mtetwa during a ceremony on the Georgia Tech campus on November 13, 2014. The presentation of this 2014 award is especially significant as Mtetwa, an advocate for women’s equality and advancement, will be the first woman to receive the prize. It also comes at a time when government leaders in Zimbabwe are persecuting human rights defenders such as Mtetwa.
===Congressman John Lewis=== On April 3, 2013, Congressman [[John Lewis (Georgia politician)|John Lewis]], an icon of American Civil Rights was honored as the third recipient of the Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage.<ref name="gatechcivil">{{cite web|url=http://www.iac.gatech.edu/news-and-events/features/04/2013/an-unflinching-advocate-for-civil-rights-john |accessdate=June 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112013415/http://www.iac.gatech.edu/news-and-events/features/04/2013/an-unflinching-advocate-for-civil-rights-john |archivedate=January 12, 2014 }}</ref>
Lewis was one of the "[[Big Six (civil rights)|Big Six]]" leaders of the Civil Rights Movement. He was the keynote speaker for the [[March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom|1963 March on Washington]], of which he was a core architect. Lewis' impact on civil rights for African-Americans has included advocating for desegregation laws and voters’ rights. A founding member and president of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), Lewis planned and led many of their activities. His personal courage was first evident when he led student sit-ins that resulted in the public accommodation of African-Americans at Nashville restaurants. He was one of the original 13 Freedom Riders who challenged legally sanctioned segregation on interstate buses. Despite repeated attacks on his dignity, physical beatings, and arrests, Lewis has remained staunchly committed to nonviolent work for social change throughout his life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://johnlewis.house.gov/john-lewis/biography |title=Biography | The Website of Congressman John Lewis, Serving the 5th Congressional District of Georgia |publisher=Johnlewis.house.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}}</ref>
"I always did what I could do to help other people," Lewis said at the ceremony while reflecting on his role in the civil rights movement. "I wanted to make a difference in order to meet the pressing need of people left out or left behind. I was inspired to find a way to a 'new way.' And this inspires me today, as I continue to keep pushing on." Georgia Tech President G.P. "Bud" Peterson said, "Congressman Lewis made his mind up to accomplish many things throughout his lifetime, and his accomplishments will transcend generations. He has dedicated his life to protecting human rights, securing civil liberties, and building what he calls 'The Beloved Community' in America. His unflinching civil rights leadership and ongoing advocacy for social change throughout his career have elevated the cause of human rights around the world."<ref name="gatechcivil"/>
===Dr. William H. Foege=== In March 2012, [[William H. Foege]] was honored as the second recipient of the Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage.<ref name="gatech2">{{cite web|url=http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=118371 |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128031359/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=118371 |archivedate=January 28, 2013 }}</ref> An American epidemiologist, Foege is best known as the architect of the surveillance and containment strategy that successfully eradicated the [[smallpox]] virus. He has also overseen, through leadership in the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]], The [[Carter Center]], and the Task Force for Child Survival (now the Task Force for Global Health), the eradication of [[Guinea worm disease]], [[polio]], and [[measles]], and the elimination of [[river blindness]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sph.emory.edu/GHI/aboutUs/advisoryBoard/foege.php |title=Rollins School of Public Health | Hubert Department of Global Health (GH) |publisher=Sph.emory.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}}</ref><ref name="usnews2007">{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-leaders/articles/2007/11/12/william-h-foege_print.html |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121174557/http://www.usnews.com/news/best-leaders/articles/2007/11/12/william-h-foege_print.html |archivedate=January 21, 2011 }}</ref> At times risking his own health and safety, Dr. Foege’s efforts have brought about extraordinary progress across an astonishing breadth of health issues, literally saving millions of lives.<ref name="usnews2007"/><ref name="gatech2"/> Speaking about Foege’s merit in receiving the Prize, Jacqueline J. Royster, Dean of the Georgia Institute of Technology [[Ivan Allen College of Liberal Arts]] said, “Like former Atlanta Mayor Ivan Allen Jr., Dr. Foege has envisioned a better world and created communities for realizing that dream in the face of seemingly insurmountable problems. His courage to do the right thing and his steadfastness, sometimes in the face of staunch opposition, has saved millions of lives and reshaped the global dialogue about what is possible in health and social progress.” Georgia Tech President Peterson also commented. “Dr. Foege’s ability to develop and implement innovative health strategies has alleviated much human suffering in our world today and for generations to come. It is our privilege to honor Dr. Foege for his deep moral commitment to humanitarian progress and his lifetime of service through Georgia Tech’s Ivan Allen Prize for Social Courage.”<ref>[https://archive.is/20121210104038/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=74321 ]</ref> Upon receiving the Prize, Foege said, “I use the occasion also to encourage everyone to believe that the health situation in the world is both dire and correctable. It takes hope and action, and absolute tenacity.”<ref>Ivan Allen College of Liberal Arts, G. I. o. T. (2012). Founder's Day: Address - William H. Foege. Videos from Founder's Day 2012 events</ref>
===Senator Sam Nunn=== The first recipient of the Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage was [[Sam Nunn]] who served as a United States Senator from Georgia from 1972–1996.
In 1991, Nunn co-authored the Nunn-Lugar Act, which set up the [[Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction]] Program that is credited with aiding [[former Soviet republics]] in ridding their territories of nuclear weapons. As of June 2014, the program had contributed to the deactivation of more than 7,600 [[nuclear warheads]], neutralized [[chemical weapons]], safeguarded [[fissile material]], converted weapons facilities for peaceful use, mitigated bio-threats, and redirected the work of former weapons scientists and engineers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://armscontrolcenter.org/publications/factsheets/fact_sheet_the_cooperative_threat_reduction_program/ |title=Fact Sheet: The Nunn-Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction Program | Center for Arms Control & Non-Proliferation |publisher=Armscontrolcenter.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}}</ref> Senator Nunn is co-chairman and CEO of the [[Nuclear Threat Initiative]] (NTI), a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization that focuses on reducing global threats from weapons of mass destruction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iac.gatech.edu/news-and-events/annual-founders-day/ivan-allen-jr-prize-recipients |accessdate=March 16, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121134541/http://www.iac.gatech.edu/news-and-events/annual-founders-day/ivan-allen-jr-prize-recipients |archivedate=January 21, 2012 }}</ref>
When announcing Senator Nunn as the recipient of the Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage, Georgia Institute of Technology President Peterson stated, “While some individuals talk about achieving world peace, Sam Nunn has actively pursued this vision and created a legacy that continues to reap results long after his exit from public office.” Peterson lauded Nunn for courage and commitment to his own moral compass, for standing up for his beliefs, and for enacting meaningful and sustainable solutions for making the world a better, and more peaceful place.<ref name="gatech1"/>
==Prize history== The Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage was established in 2010 by the Georgia Institute of Technology. The international award honors individuals whose life and work embody the moral courage personified by former Atlanta Mayor Ivan Allen Jr.<ref name="gatech3">{{cite web|url=http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=58155 |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320015108/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/news/release.php?nid=58155 |archivedate=March 20, 2012 }}</ref> The Prize underscores the Institute’s mission to improve the human condition by recognizing those around the globe who, like Mayor Allen, have risked everything to stand up for moral principle and have made a positive difference in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/home/ |accessdate=September 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120909052514/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/home/ |archivedate=September 9, 2012 }}</ref>
The Prize is funded in perpetuity by a grant from the Wilbur and Hilda Glenn Family Foundation.<ref name="gatech3"/>
The prize's forerunner was the [[Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Progress and Service]], which was awarded annually from 2001–2010 by the Georgia Tech.<ref name="gatech3"/>
== Nominating committee == === About the committee === The nominating committee is responsible for assessing candidates who meet the requirements of the prize, demonstrating social courage in adverse circumstances. Each year after deliberation, the committee submits a nominee to the president of the Georgia Institute of Technology, who makes the final selection.
=== Voting members === Joseph R. Bankoff, Chair, President & CEO, [[Woodruff Arts Center]]; Susan E. Eisenhower, Chairman Emeritus, [[The Eisenhower Institute]], [[United States Department of Energy]], [[Blue Ribbon Commission]] on America's Nuclear Future; Dr. Helene D. Gayle, President and CEO, [[CARE U.S.A.]]; Dr. Kenneth J. Knoespel, McEver Professor of Engineering and the Liberal Arts, Georgia Institute of Technology; Charles H. McTier, Retired President, [[Robert W. Woodruff]] Foundation; The Honorable Sam Nunn, former U.S. Senator from Georgia, Co-Chairman & CEO, [[Nuclear Threat Initiative]], Chairman, [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] (CSIS), Co‐Chairman, Euro‐Atlantic Security Initiative (EASI), faculty member, [[The Sam Nunn School of International Affairs]], Georgia Institute of Technology; Dr. Catherine Ross, Director and Harry West Chair, [http://www.cqgrd.gatech.edu/ Center for Quality Growth & Regional Development], [http://www.coa.gatech.edu/ College of Architecture] Georgia Institute of Technology; Dr. Jacqueline Jones Royster, Dean, Ivan Allen College of the Liberal Arts, Georgia Institute of Technology; William J. Todd, Professor of the Practice, Ernest [[Scheller College of Business]], Georgia Institute of Technology<ref name="gatech4">[http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/nominating-committee/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818184650/http://ivanallenprize.gatech.edu/nominating-committee/ |date=August 18, 2011 }}</ref>
=== Non-voting members === Inman Allen, Former Chairman, Allen Workspace, Atlanta, Georgia; Marta H. Garcia, Assistant Vice President for Development, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, Georgia<ref name="gatech4"/>
== Award ceremony == Presentation of the Ivan Allen Jr. Prize for Social Courage takes place on the Georgia Tech campus. The Symposia and festivities highlight research, teaching, endeavors, and innovation that address global challenges related to Mayor Allen’s legacy and the work of the recipient.

'''Joseph A. Jordan Jr.''' (1924 - 14 June 1991) was an [[African Americans|African American]] lawyer and [[Civil and political rights|civil rights activist]]. He worked as a lawyer and judge and was part of the lawsuit heard before the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] that ended [[Poll tax|poll taxes]].
== Biography == Jordan was raised in [[Norfolk, Virginia]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17430524/the_pittsburgh_courier/|title=Paralyzed Vet Gets Degree; Plans Law Career, Matrimony|last=|first=|date=1949-07-02|work=The Pittsburgh Courier|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=6|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> He went to the [[Booker T. Washington High School (Norfolk, Virginia)|Booker T. Washington High School]] and went on to the [[Virginia Union University]].<ref name=":2" /> In 1943, he went into the United States Army and fought overseas with the 846 Gas Company and the [[Divisions of the United States Army|67th Infantry]] during [[World War II]].<ref name=":2" /> In September of 1945, he was injured when his jeep slid off of the highway into a [[Land mine|mine field]].<ref name=":2" /> The accident caused him to become [[Paralysis|paralyzed]] from the waist down so Jordan used a [[wheelchair]].<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17452246/the_news_leader/|title=Judge Jordan Censored, Plans Return to Bench|last=|first=|date=1979-08-30|work=The News Leader|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=15|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> Jordan went on to earn a degree in [[sociology]].<ref name=":2" /> He earned his law degree from [[Brooklyn Law School]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17402687/daily_press/|title=Joseph A. Jordan Jr., Civil Rights Advocate|last=|first=|date=1991-06-16|work=Daily Press|access-date=2018-02-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=52|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> Later, he studied [[Labour law|labor law]] at [[New York University]].<ref name=":0" />
In 1954, he set up a law practice in Norfolk.<ref name=":0" /> In 1955, when the state of [[Virginia]] planned to create a referendum to allow [[Racial segregation in the United States|segregation]], Jordan filed an [[injunction]] to block the vote.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17431316/the_progressindex/|title=Virginia Faces Test on Plans for Referendum|last=|first=|date=1955-12-07|work=The Progress-Index|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=1|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> When Jordan and another civil rights activist, [[Evelyn Thomas Butts]], were restrained from picketing a supermarket for not hiring black people in high level jobs, Jordan fought the restraining order, but lost.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.lva.virginia.gov/public/trailblazers/res/Butts_Victor-Expects-Another-Fight.pdf|title=Victor Expects Another Fight|last=McAllister|first=Bill|date=25 March 1966|work=The Virginian-Pilot|access-date=14 February 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|via=Library of Virginia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17403158/daily_press/|title=Norfolk Judge Halts Pickets at Be-Lo Store|last=|first=|date=1960-03-15|work=Daily Press|access-date=2018-02-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=9|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> Jordan was involved in several anti-segregation cases in 1961, 1962 and 1964 in Virginia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/9238562/the_progressindex/|title=Massive Suit Hits Danville Segregation|last=|first=|date=1962-08-22|work=The Progress-Index|access-date=2018-02-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=14|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17451206/kingsport_news/|title=Store Hires Two Negro Clerks|last=|first=|date=1961-03-16|work=Kingsport News|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=14|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17451388/the_news_leader/|title=Old Dominion News Briefs|last=|first=|date=1964-02-07|work=The News Leader|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=5|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In November of 1963, Butts hired him to sue the state for requiring a [[poll tax]] to vote.<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17402384/daily_press/|title=Ceremony Marks Poll Tax Repeal|last=|first=|date=1996-03-27|work=Daily Press|access-date=2018-02-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=13|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The case was dismissed by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit|4th Circuit Court of Appeals]] in 1964.<ref name=":22" /><ref name=":5" /> In May of 1964, Jordan and Butts filed another suit which accused the state of violating four amendments of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]] with the poll tax.<ref name=":5" /> Butts' case against the poll tax was appealed to the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] and was bundled with another case, ''[[Harper v. Virginia State Board of Elections]]'' in 1966''.''<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Poll_Tax#start_entry|title=Poll Tax|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia Virginia|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-02-13}}</ref>
When the case went before the Supreme Court, Jordan argued that the poll tax laws had successfully barred black people not only from voting, but from holding office.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://ideastations.org/radio/news/patriotism-perseverance-and-end-poll-tax|title=Patriotism, Perseverance and the End of the Poll Tax|last=Komp|first=Catherine|date=2016-03-17|work=Community Idea Stations|access-date=2018-02-14|language=en}}</ref> Jordan said, "Almost like a magic wand after the passage of this law, these poll tax laws, not a single Negro has sat in the Virginia General Assembly, and not a single Negro has held a single elected state office in the state of Virginia."<ref name=":3" /> The decision was made by the Supreme Court in two months and they decided that the poll tax or voting fee did violate the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|14th Amendment]].<ref name=":3" />
In 1968, Jordan was elected to the Norfolk City Council and became the first black person to hold the seat since 1889.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17452005/the_progressindex/|title=400 Marchers Hit Norfolk|last=|first=|date=1968-05-17|work=The Progress-Index|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=6|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In 1971, Jordan was the only black member of the city council.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17426032/the_corpus_christi_callertimes/|title=Busing Blamed for Flight of Whites from Norfolk|last=|first=|date=1971-12-10|work=The Corpus Christi Caller-Times|access-date=2018-02-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=2|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In 1972, he became the vice-mayor of Norfolk.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RcrzCQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA83&dq=%22joseph%20a%20jordan%22&pg=PA83#v=onepage&q=%22joseph%20a%20jordan%22&f=false|title=On This Day in Norfolk, Virginia History|last=Downing|first=Sarah|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|year=2015|isbn=9781626197039|location=|pages=83|language=en}}</ref> In 1974, Jordan resigned as vice-mayor in protest, "saying the city is being run by the Norfolk Redevelopment Authority rather than City Council."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17452088/the_news_leader/|title=Norfolk Vice Mayor Resigns|last=|first=|date=1974-11-06|work=The News Leader|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=15|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
Jordan was appointed to the [[Virginia General District Court|General District Court]] on July 1,1977.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17425846/daily_press/|title=Judge Not Unfit, Attorneys Argue|last=|first=|date=1979-06-06|work=Daily Press|access-date=2018-02-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=8|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> He was one of only a few African American state judges at the time.<ref name=":1" /> He retired from this position in 1986.<ref name=":0" />
Jordan died at the [[List of Veterans Affairs medical facilities|Veterans Administration Hospital]] in [[Hampton, Virginia|Hampton]] on June 14, 1991.<ref name=":0" /> A [[public library]] in Norfolk is named after Jordan.<ref name=":3" /> A foundation in his name, the Joe Jordan Foundation, raised funds in his name to build the [[Martin Luther King Jr.|Martin Luther King Jr]]. memorial in Norfolk.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://pilotonline.com/guides/african-american-today/article_f447b59b-b20e-53b8-9ab6-4d3124640fb4.html|title=Memorial's story reflects King's vision|last=Parker|first=Stacy|date=1 February 2012|work=Virginian-Pilot|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> The memorial was dedicated in 2000 and had been proposed in the 70s by Jordan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17455276/daily_press/|title=Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Dedicated|last=|first=|date=2000|work=Daily Press|access-date=2018-02-14|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|pages=10|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>

'''Kahrizak Detention Center''' (in Persian: بازداشتگاه کهریزک) is a detainment facility operated by the [[Judicial system of Iran]] in southern [[Tehran]].
==Before 2009 election protests== Authorities first made plans for the Kahrizak detention center in 2001. The center's cells, located underground, were apparently built without free access to fresh air and toilet facilities.<ref>{{cite web |script-title=fa:گزارش تکان دهنده از برخوردهای صورت گرفته با متهمین با عنوان " اراذل و اوباش" |publisher= Committee of Human Rights Reporters |language = Persian|date= 2007-07-31 |url= http://www.schrr.net/spip.php?article302 |accessdate =2009-07-29}}</ref> With the appointment of [[Ahmad-Reza Radan]] to the post of Tehran police chief, the center became a key site for carrying out the "Public Security Plan" targeting drug addicts and so-called "thugs and louts" endangering public morality.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=fa:دستور تعطیلی گوانتاناموی ایران صادر شد |publisher=[[Rooz Online]] |date=2009-07-29 |language=Persian |url=http://www.roozonline.com/persian/news/newsitem/article/2009/july/29//-16183e1262.html |accessdate=2009-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801044636/http://www.roozonline.com/persian/news/newsitem/article/2009/july/29/-16183e1262.html |archivedate=August 1, 2009 }}</ref>
Reports of inhumane treatment of the prisoners at Kahrizak were released, with some comparing the conditions there unfavorably to even the notorious political [[Prison 209|ward 209]] of [[Evin prison]].<ref>{{cite web |script-title=fa:افشای نام بازداشتگاهی در عمق زمین ومخوف تر از 209 اوین |publisher = Peik Net |date = 2007-07-30 |url = http://www.peiknet.com/1386/08mordad/10/page/32kahrizak.htm|language=Persian |accessdate = 2009-07-29}}</ref> Opposition groups have published unverified reports of human rights abuses and as many as 6,000 deaths inside the prison during the years 2007 and 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title = Shocking crimes in mullahs' medieval prison of Kahrizak unveiled |publisher = National Council of Resistance |date= 2008-12-13 |url = http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/5867/106/ |accessdate = 2009-07-29}}</ref>
==2009 election protests== Several thousand civilians and activists were arrested after the [[2009 Iranian election protests|disputed presidential election in 2009]]. The head of the national security forces, [[Esmail Ahmadi-Moghaddam]], stated in an interview with state television on August 5, 2009 that only the most dangerous offenders involved in the election protests were to be delivered to the Kahrizak center, which has a 50 prisoner capacity. The rest were to be taken to [[Evin prison]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Interview with Esmail Ahmadi-Moghaddam (audio only) |language=Persian |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yg0atAMruPE&eurl=http%3A%2F%2F |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=2009-08-06}}</ref> Tehran riot police and Basij members used other official and unofficial sites to detain suspects charged with endangering national security and public safety during the protests, including the [[Level -4 detention center]] in the [[Ministry of Interior (Iran)|Interior Ministry]] building.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=fa:تایید وجود بازداشتگاه منفی 4 در وزارت کشور |publisher=[[Rooz Online]] |date=2007-07-30 |url=http://www.roozonline.com/persian/news/newsitem/article/2009/july/30//4-17.html |language=Persian |accessdate=2009-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801035022/http://www.roozonline.com/persian/news/newsitem/article/2009/july/30/4-17.html |archivedate=August 1, 2009 }}</ref> Ahmadi-Moghaddam further admitted in his television interview that many of the 140 prisoners he claimed to be housed at Kahrizak were low priority suspects. [[Mohsen Ruholamini]], the son of a conservative politician who had supported pragmatic presidential candidate [[Mohsen Rezaei]], was among the Kahrizak prisoners.<ref name=Straits>{{cite web | title = Iran to prosecute jail officials | publisher = [[Straits Times]] | date = 2009-08-04 | url = http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/World/Story/STIStory_412612.html | accessdate = 2009-08-06 }}</ref>
On August 9, 2009, in a letter to the Chairman of the Expediency Discernment Council of Iran, [[Mehdi Karroubi]] demanded investigation of Iranian prisons for possible tortures and in particular sexual harassment of men and women.<ref>[http://www.etemademelli.ir/published/0/00/65/6571/]</ref><ref>[http://www.economist.com/world/mideast-africa/displaystory.cfm?story_id=14222321 Iran and human rights: The crackdown]</ref> On August 19, he wrote to parliament speaker Ali Larijani, asking to meet with him, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, judiciary chief Ayatollah Sadeq Larijani, former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and the state prosecutor to "personally present my documents and evidence over the cases of sexual abuse in some prisons specially Kahrizak."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/Iran/idUSDAH93169320090819 |title= Iran reformer says he wants to present rape evidence |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2009-08-19}} </ref>
[[Ali Larijani]] and [[Sadeq Larijani]] (Judiciary committee) both officially rejected his claims and [[Ali Khamenei]]'s representatives, and Vice Chairman of National Security Commission of the parliament demanded Karroubi's arrest.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ixeFBxfLzaSjs8Mb8cuFmtPOT6-wD9ALTVP00 dead link]</ref>{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}}
==Detainee abuse== The release of some prisoners from Kahrizak on July 28, 2009 was followed by a number of testimonials in the foreign and opposition press on conditions inside the prison. Various news articles have reported on cramped and squalid cells where prisoners were routinely [[verbally abused]] and beaten by guards, some to death. [[Ahmad-Reza Radan]], according to one account, daily took part in these beatings.<ref>{{cite web | script-title=fa:وقایع کهریزک، جنایت علیه بشریت | publisher = Peyke Iran | date = 2009-07-28 | url = http://www.peykeiran.com/Content.aspx?ID=4385 |language=Persian | accessdate = 2009-07-28}}</ref> Ahmadi-Moghaddam has since denied these reports about Radan as unfounded rumors.<ref name=Rooz>{{cite web|title=Kahrizak Detention Facility Will Be Renovated |publisher=[[Rooz Online]] |date=2009-08-06 |url=http://www.roozonline.com/english/news/newsitem/article/2009/august/06//kahrizak-detention-facility-will-be-renovated.html |accessdate=2009-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090814182315/http://www.roozonline.com/english/news/newsitem/article/2009/august/06/kahrizak-detention-facility-will-be-renovated.html |archivedate=August 14, 2009 }}</ref> [[Mohsen Ruholamini]] and [[Amir Javadifar]] were two of the prisoners reported to have died from [[torture]] at Kahrizak.<ref>{{cite news | title = Son of leading scientist dies in jail as fears grow over fate of Iran's political prisoners | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2009-07-26 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jul/26/iran-political-prisoners-mohsen-rouholamini | accessdate = 2009-07-28 | location=London | first=Robert | last=Tait}}</ref> The medical report on Ruholamini's death originally stated that Ruholomini died of "physical stress, the effects of being held in bad conditions, multiple blows and severe injuries to the body." The physician who wrote this report, [[Ramin Pourandarjani]], subsequently died in mysterious circumstances in police headquarters.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/09/01/world/main5279285.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Iranian Doctor Confirms Prison Abuse Death | date=2009-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6920788.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=Suspicions over heart attack death of Iranian doctor who knew too much | first=Martin | last=Fletcher | date=2009-11-18 | accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref> The autopsy report for Javadifar stated that his death was caused by blunt trauma injury from severe beating.<ref name=Daragahi>{{cite news |title=Imprisoned Iranian protesters share a bond forged in hell |author=Daragahi B, Mostaghim R |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2010-02-14 |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation-and-world/la-fg-iran-prison14-2010feb14,0,3068797.story }}</ref>
==National reactions== Following massive arrests of civilians and reformist activists by Iranian police, a number of Iranian intellectuals and reformist activists condemned the detentions, and called for the release of the imprisoned protesters.
In an exceptionally strong and critical speech,<ref name=NYT20090728 >{{cite news | author = Robert F. Worth and Sharon otterman | title = Iran to Release Some Post-Election Detainees | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = 2009-07-28 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/29/world/middleeast/29iran.html | accessdate = 2009-07-28 }}</ref> the Iranian opposition leader, [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] spoke out on July 17, 2009 against the arrests and killings of protesters. Erstwhile prime minister Moussavi said, "How can it be that the leaders of our country do not cry out and shed tears about these tragedies? ... Can they not see it, feel it? These things are blackening our country, blackening all our hearts. If we remain silent, it will destroy us all and take us to hell."
Grand Ayatollah [[Hosein-Ali Montazeri]] on 29 July demanded prosecution of anybody responsible for abuses. "Can the government deceive people by closing a detention center and blaming all the faults on a building?" he said. "What benefit does the government gain from the crisis, except angering the majority of the people and weakening the Islamic republic?"<ref name=TG20090729>{{cite news | author=Lee Keath, Associated Press Writer | title = Iran to begin first trials of protesters | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2009-07-30 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/8633337 | accessdate = 2009-07-30 | location=London}}</ref> He added "Was the regime of the Shah able to resist the wave of dissatisfaction by using terror, oppression, [[censorship]], torture, forced confessions and lying propaganda?"<ref name=AP20090730>{{cite news | title = Iranian police use force against graveside rally | publisher = KMOV, St Louis | date = 2009-07-30 | url = http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_IRAN_ELECTION | accessdate = 2009-07-30}}</ref>
Grand Ayatollah [[Asadollah Bayat-Zanjani]] said: "We are witnessing sorrowful acts committed in the name of the regime and under the banner of God that bring pain to the heart of all supporters of the Islamic republic."<ref name=HP20090729>{{cite news | title = Details Emerge Of Iran's Abuse Of Protesters: Beatings, Forced To Lick Toilet Bowls | publisher = Huffington Post | date = 2009-07-29 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/07/29/details-emerge-of-irans-a_n_247043.html | accessdate = 2009-07-29}}</ref>
==Closure and investigations== Despite numerous reports of death and torture of arrested protesters in Iranian prisons, neither Iranian leader nor the Head of Judicial System took any measure to stop the crimes.<ref name=ABC20090728 >{{cite web | author = Anne Barker | title = Iran accused of beating activists | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | date = 2009-07-28 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/07/09/2620865.htm?section=justin | accessdate = 2009-07-28 }}</ref>
The crimes were so grave that even several well known conservative politicians like Ali Motahhari expressed concerns about them.<ref name=TT20090728 >{{cite web | title = MP urges Judiciary chief to seriously address detentions issue | publisher = [[Tehran Times]] | date = 2009-07-28 | url = http://www.tehrantimes.com/Index_view.asp?code=199725 | accessdate = 2009-07-28 }}</ref>
It was only after the death of the son of one of the conservative politicians, that the Iranian leader [[Ali Khamenei]] and head of Judicial System, [[Hashemi Shahroudi]] stepped in and ordered the closure of Kahrizak detention center.<ref name=Reuters20090728 >{{cite news | author = Parisa Hafezi and Zahra Hosseinian | title = Iran's Khamenei orders closure of detention center | publisher = [[Reuters]] | date = 2009-07-28 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE56R1J620090728?sp=true | accessdate = 2009-07-28 }}</ref>
An official announcement was made on August 5, 2009 that three prison wardens were arrested in connection with the torture of detainees at Kahrizak.<ref name=Straits />
On December 19, 2009, Iranian authorities acknowledged that at least three protesters had been beaten to death in the Kahrizak jail. Twelve prison officials were charged with crimes, including murder.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/20/world/middleeast/20iran.html?scp=1&sq=kahrizak&st=cse | work=The New York Times | title=Iran Charges 12 at Prison Over Death of Protesters | first=Robert F. | last=Worth | date=2009-12-20 | accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref>
The Iranian parliament assigned a committee to investigate the incidents.<ref name=Fox20090728 >{{cite news |title=Iran Releases 140 Prisoners, Closes Prison in Nod to Allegations of Abuse |work=Fox News |date=2009-07-28 |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,535063,00.html }}</ref> The committee released a report in January 2010 that implicated former Tehran prosecutor-general [[Saeed Mortazavi]] as being behind the abuses. Days before the report was issued, Iranian President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] appointed Mortazavi as his special advisor on smuggling, which in effect was an attempt to shield Mortazavi from prosecution.<ref name=Daragahi/> On August 19, 2015, Mortazavi was acquitted on charges connected to the torture and deaths of three young men at Kahrizak in 2009,<ref>[http://www.iranhumanrights.org/2015/08/kahrizak-mortazavi/ Former Tehran Prosecutor Acquitted of Charges in Kahrizak Murders despite Overwhelming Evidence]</ref> but the court's decision was appealed. On September 2016, Mortazavi issued a public apology for the prisoner killings.<ref>[https://en.radiozamaneh.com/articles/notorious-former-tehran-prosecutor-issues-public-apology-for-prisoner-killings/ Radio Zamaneh: Notorious former Tehran prosecutor issues public apology for prisoner killings]</ref>
==Re-opening of Kahrizak detention center== Ahmadi-Moghaddam on August 5, 2009 stated that the security forces were re-building the Kahrizak facility to meet national prison standards and would re-open its doors in one month.<ref name=Rooz />
==References and notes== <references/>
